She is applying for a loan of $1200.00, and she wants to pay it off in one year.

La Srita. T. is un apersona muy emprendedora ella tiene ya un año con su negocio una Papeleria,esta muy contenta por ello pero quiere crecer su negocio y comprar mas mercancia para que se incrementen las ventas por lo cual esta solicitando un prestamo de $1200.00 Dllrs los cuales quiere pagar en un plazo de un año.

loans.use: Buy more merchandise

loans.name: Ines

texts.en:
Mrs.C. is a very organized person. She started her business last year in the Grocery field and the business is running great!! Her plans for this year are to improve it with more variety of products and increase sales. That's why she is applying for a $1200.00 loan, payable in 12 months.

La Sra. C. es una persona muy organizada, ella comenzo su negocio el año pasado y el negocio a funcionado muy bien!!, pero sus planes para este año son mejorar con mas variedad de productos e incrementar las ventas, por lo cual esta aplicando para un prestamo de $1200.00 dllrs pagaderos en 12 meses.

loans.use: Buy merchandise

loans.name: Maricela

texts.en:
Miss R. started her cosmetic sales business in December, 2005, and the business is running great. She loves to sell and make more customers every day.
In 2007 wants to sell more products and she is
applying for a $1200.00 loan, which she wants to pay off in 12 months.

<Español>

la srita R. comenzo su negocio de venta de productos cosmetologicos en Dic del 2005 y el negocio va muy bien, a ella le encanta vender y conocer mas clientes.

este 2007 quiere vender mas productos por lo cual
esta aplicando para un prestamo de $1200.00 Dllrs
el cual quiere pagar en 12 meses.

loans.use: To buy cosmetic products

loans.name: Juana

texts.en:
Mrs. R. started her snack business last year and she has a large number of customers. This year she wants to sell more and have more clients, and she wants to sell new snacks. She is applying for a $1200.00 loan, which she wants to pay off in 12 months.

la señora R. comenzo su negocio de snacks el año pasado y tiene un gran numero de clientes pero este año ella quiere vender mas por lo que piensa vender diferentes productos, ella esta solicitando un prestamo de $1200.00 Dllrs y lo piensa pagar en 12 meses.

loans.use: To buy merchandise

loans.name: Eunice

texts.en:
Eunice is married with one child who attends school. She also takes care of the children of his deceased sister and brother. She is educated up to level 12. She started her clothing business in 2001 with funds from a merry-go-round. The business has been able to generate income for her family’s needs.

Given the loan she wants to buy goods in wholesale and sell them at retail. The loan term is 12 months.

loans.use: Business expansion

loans.name: Everline

texts.en:
Everline is married and has two children that attend school. She also takes care of her sister and her child. She is educated up to level 12 and she has taken business management and loan use training through Rural Agency for Development (Rafode). She started her used clothing business in 2000 with capital of $200. The business has grown since then under her management.

She is seeking a loan to expand her business by opening branches in other market areas surrounding Kisumu.

She intends to use the profit to take care of the family and furnish her house.

loans.use: Business expansion

loans.name: Papaloa

texts.en: Papaloa manages the women’s committee in her village of Manono. She is a highly skilled weaver of fine mats, which are traditional treasures in Samoa.  These mats are important cultural objects used for special occasions like weddings, funerals, and title bestowments. Papaloa's  business specializes in providing these beautiful mats for local customers and to the thousands of tourists who visit Samoa year round. Papaloa requests a capital loan in the amount of $675 to purchase pandanus leaves, dyes, paints, feathers and flax for her fine weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase materials for weaving fine mats like: pandanus leaves, dyes, paints, feathers and flax

loans.name: Emily

texts.en:
Emily is married with five children who all attend school. She takes care of four orphaned children. In 2001, she started her clothing business and she has been able to expanded her business through good management.

She seeks a loan of $800 to stock a variety of new clothes to attract a wide more customers.

She intends to use the profit for school fees for the children, buy a plot and build a home for the family.

loans.use: Business diversification

loans.name: Mativa

texts.en: Mativa, 29 grew up in the village of Sogi, a community where crab fishing is a major source of income. Delicious crab is the most abundant item on the seafood menus in many Samoan restaurants. Overseas, crab meals are very expensive, but in Samoa, the crab dishes are fresh and inexpensive and attract many tourists at mealtime. Mativa's business is successful because of her expertise in the art of fishing and hunting for crabs at the right time. She sells to locals and businesses around town. Sometimes she caters family events. She is requesting a capital loan in the amount of  $875.00 to purchase materials that will increase her crab catch.

loans.use: To purchase additional crab traps, googles, torches, and nets

loans.name: Romanus

texts.en:
Romanus is married and has five children; four attend school. He also takes care of three orphaned children of his brother. He is educated to level 8 and he started his clothing business in 2000 and has been managing the business since then. The business has been able to generate income for the family’s needs. He hopes to increase his income by expanding his business.

Given the loan he intends to expand his business by buying cloths in bulk and targeting other markets where he has not been able to reach yet.

loans.use: Business expansion

loans.name: Lautalie

texts.en: Daily life for Lautalie, 44, is weaving fine mats to sell to tourists and locals. Her business is successful, because she understands the quality and design her customers are looking for in these hand-crafted mats. Tourists appreciate the artfulness of the mats, and locals appreciate her knowledge of traditional themes, which they use for special occasions.

loans.use: To purchase materials for weaving fine mats like pandanus leaves, paints, flx, feathers, dyes and some cutters and clippers

loans.name: Faaasu

texts.en: The most common source of income in Samoa is growing produce. The majority of families rely heavily on their land and selling their produce to earn a living. Faaasu grew up on a plantation and now grows and sells bananas. Her business is successful because she supplies several markets. She sells once a week at the local market. Her price varies according to the number of banana sellers at the market. When there are many banana sellers, she reduces her price. But when there are few sellers and high demand, she can charge more. She also sells to local businesses that produce snacks made from bananas, like banana chips. Selling bananas is a most successful business in Samoa because of the numerous buyers, some of them producing for overseas markets. Samoans overseas love snacks made from Samoan bananas. Faaasu is requesting a capital loan for $875.00 to increase her banana yield organically.

loans.use: To purchase banana planting materials, organic fertilizers and pesticides

loans.name: Monica

texts.en:
Monica is married with five children; two children attend college, two are in secondary school and one child is in primary school. She has been in the clothing business since 1990. She previously took a loan from Krep and successfully repaid it.

She is seeking a loan to expand her business and diversify her line of products for motorcycle taxis which are becoming common in Kisumu and the surrounding areas.

She will use her income to pay for her children’s college fees and for her family’s needs.

loans.use: Business expansion

loans.name: Fotu

texts.en: Fotu is one of the few people that has the ability and the recipe for creating one of the oldest Samoan delicacies, traditional pudding. Because of the time, lack of knowledge and effort involved, this pudding is rarely made or sold any more. Fotu's business will attract locals who will love the pudding, and tourists who will be able to sample this delicious dish. Restaurants may also be interested in buying her pudding so they can offer this tradtional dish on their menu. Fotu is requesting a capital loan in the amount of $650.00 to purchase the ingredients that will help her to produce enough pudding to grow her business.

loans.use: To purchase coconut, baking soda, flour, sugar and other ingredients in making Samoan pudding

loans.name: Palasi

texts.en: Palasi is a mother of five who never attended school. Her children now go to schools in the village. Though Palasi does not have a formal education, she learned the skills of a farmer on the plantation where she was raised. She lives 200-300 meters inland from the main road. Before she joined the lending program, Palasi and her family lived without electricity and running water. Their water came mainly from rainwater. She has applied for three loans, which have helped her develop her plantation and given her access to a power supply. She is requesting a capital loan in the amount of $850.00 so she can continue to develop her farming business.

loans.use: To purchase organic fertilizers, fungicides and pesticides

loans.name: Joice

texts.en:
Joice is married with two children. One attends school. Joice was educated until level 7 when her parents passed away and she could no longer afford the school fees. She started her food business one year ago with capital of $100 which she got from her husband. She deals in both wholesale and retail in different markets.

Given the loan, she plans to buy tomatoes in bulk to maximize on profit. The loan term is 12 months.

loans.use: Expand her business

loans.name: Julia

texts.en: Julia, 46, grew up on a plantation and life on the land is what she understands and knows very well. She produces taro, bananas, and other fruits, which are sold at the Fugalei market once a week. Julia’s knowledge of farming and her understanding of seasonal planting and protecting crops from insects comes from her long experience working the land. She is requesting a capital loan of $875.00 so she can purchase organic materials to help insure a healthy yield and grow her business.

loans.use: To purchase organic fertilizers, fungicides, and pesticides

loans.name: Faafetai

texts.en: Fishing is a family business. The skills needed for catching the best and biggest fish are usually passed on from the fathers to the sons. Faafetai's case is a bit different. When she was widowed and left to raise a family of four on her own, she had to take over her husband's fishing business. Using a small loan from the SPBD microcredit program, she was able to succeed. Now, she is expanding her fishing business and requests a capital loan of $1,175.00 to purchase a cooler for storing her catch, plywood and fishing nets. Her business will continue to be successful, because seafood is in high demand from local restaurants, and she knows how to catch the best and biggest fish.

loans.use: To purchase cooler, plywood, and fishing nets

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace is married and has three children; two of whom attend school. She also cares for her brother’s child. Grace lives with her husband and children in their own house which was built by her husband. She attended school until level 8 and then was forced to drop out because she could not afford the school fees. She started her food business in 2000 with capital $100 and has managed the business to date.

She seeks a loan to increase her stock and sell it in wholesale and retail.

loans.use: Business expansion

loans.name: Eunice

texts.en:
Eunice is married and has three children who all attend school. Eunice dropped out of school in level 8 due to lack of school fees. She cares for the five children of her brother and sister who passed away.

She seeks a loan to expand her business and diversify it which will enable her to attract more customers. She also wants to expand her business to reach out to other markets.

She intends to use the profit to help her family with medical care, clothing, and savings for future use.

loans.use: Business Expansion

loans.name: Lilian

texts.en:
Lilian is married and has one child who attends school. She is educated to level 10 and left early due to marriage. She started her shoe business in 2003 with capital of $220 that was given to her by the husband.

She previously took a loan out from Krep and successfully repaid it. Since the first loan helped her improve her income greatly so she could take care of her family’s needs, she now wants another loan to expand her business and generate additional income.

The loan term is for 12 months and she is capable of repaying the loan as she has a good repayment history.

loans.use: Business expansion

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose is married and has two children that attend school. She is educated up to level 12. She has been trained in business management and loan use by the Rural Agency for Development (Rafode). She started her restaurant business in 2003 and she has managed the business successfully to date.

She is seeking a loan to buy restaurant equipment which will enable her prepare a variety of food to cater to all her customer’s tastes.

She will use the profit to buy medical insurance for the family and buy a cow for her father at home.

loans.use: Buy restaurant equipment

loans.name: Ivan

texts.en:
Ivan R. has been a farmer and a cattle rancher in Salitre his whole life. Although he only has a primary education, he has been able to be successful in cattle ranching and rice cultivation. After working in his father's ranch as a young man, he decided to acquire his own land and start his own family. He has 8 children ages 20, 18, 17, 16, 14, 7, 5 and 1. His older children have already finished their studies and work with him on the ranch while his other kids are still in school. Along with rice cultivation he will also make some investment in cattle with the loan.

Ivan is part of the first Communal Bank in the new Mifex Rural Finance Program. All of the members of the Resistencia Communal Bank are part of an Association of Rice Farmers in Salitre named Resistencia. They will use the microloans to prepare the lands and cultivate rice on their farms. Because they form part of a communal bank, they are all each other's guarantors for the loan. This means that if for some reason one person in the group cannot fully repay the loan, the other borrowers and the Resistencia Association are responsible for the amount that is missing. The members of the bank also participate in a program designed to teach and encourage savings among the group. Promoting savings is often forgotten in many microfinance programs, but is imperative for the communities Mifex works with to have capital reserved for future investments or unexpected difficulties.

Loan Use and Repayment

The loans in this sector will be used to create water deposits that will prevent flooding in the case of heavy rains or store water in case of droughts. They will also be used to treat the land prior to farming, to plant the seeds and purchase fertilizer. The loan repayment schedule is also different from the typical microentrepreneur. Because farmers see the profits from their investments 5 or 6 months after making their initial expenditures, Mifex asks them only to pay 50% of the capital in the first 6 months of the loan. The rest of the debt must be paid in the seventh and final month.

Below is more information about Salitre compiled by the staff at Mifex when evaluating the potential of the sector for the Rural Finance Program.

Economy of Salitre

Salitre is a rural sector in the Province of Guayas known as the capital of Montuvios (montuvio is a cowboy) with approximately 30,000 inhabitants. The main economic activities are herding and agriculture which make up about 80% of the economy. The infrastructure and basic services are poor, especially the roads and water services.

Salitre is highly dedicated to farming rice and cattle ranching. Rice is a crop that yields about every four months. In order to farm rice, the environment must be very humid and there must be a high volume of water. The lack of a structured water system makes it difficult for the small farmers to be highly productive. The best months for cultivating rice are early in the year when it is the rainy season in the coast of Ecuador.

Salitre is a national tourist attraction as many Ecuadorians visit the fresh water Salitre River. There are cottages, small restaurants and water attractions that people come to enjoy.

Access to Credit

There is not a single financial institution that provides services to the productive sector of the local economy. The only access to credit comes from loan sharks who charge extremely high interest rates averaging around 20% a month. The locals are also exploited by the intermediaries that buy their products in order to commercialize them in the city and to export abroad. These intermediaries buy crops in advance at very low prices, finance soil at extremely high prices and often provide emergency loans for even higher interest rates than the loan sharks.

Risks

Salitre is a dangerous sector considering it is in the rural area. There is a high incidence of robbery of cattle that results in many of the ranch owners owning weapons to protect their property. Because the police are not present in these areas, farmers and ranchers must apply their own laws and provide their own security. In some instances they have formed their own cooperatives and associations to have a community crime prevention effort.

Salitre is in the lowlands of Ecuador and is vulnerable to flooding in the rainy season. In the event of a heavy rainy season, often at its worse when El Niño occurs, the farmers of rice lose many of their crops. All this is due to a lack of infrastructure in the area.

loans.use: Invest in cattle and prepare his lands for rice cultivation

loans.name: Kwarteng

texts.en: In Ghana, kente is a traditional cloth used for every occasion. G. has been in this business for over 7 years. She has acquired skills in trading from the TEACH lending programmes and is a client of the Kraban Support Foundation. She needs a Kiva loan of $950 to expand her business.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Gladys

texts.en: Gladys sells rice porridge, locally called "rice water". She sells within the community especially to school children. She has participated in the TEACH lending programs and is a client of Kraban Support Foundation. She needs a Kiva loan of $500 to increase her business.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en: The TEACH lending programme has taught Elizabeth on how to trade with her customers. She is a client of Kraban Support Foundation and needs a Kiva loan of $1000 to expand her business.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Esther

texts.en: Esther sells different kind of footwear within her community. She has acquired skills from the TEACH lending programmes and is a client of Kraban Support Foundation. She needs a Kiva loan of $950 to expand her business.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Awo

texts.en: Awo sells oil and vegetables in the community where she lives. She has participated in the TEACH lending programs and is a client of Kraban Support Foundation. She needs a Kiva loan of $500 to increase her business.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en: Rebecca operates a provisions store in her community. She sells all kinds of food items in the store. She is a client of Kraban Support Foundation and participated in the TEACH lending programs. She needs a Kiva loan of $950 to increase her business.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Mariama

texts.en: Auntie Mari sells different kinds of cosmetics products. She has been a client of Kraban Support Foundation for 3 years and acquired skills from the TEACH lending programs. She needs a Kiva loan of $800 to increase her business.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Doris

texts.en:
Doris is a client of Kraban Support Foundation. She sells wheat brans in the community where she lives. TEACH lending programs have improved her business and she now sells many bags of wheat brans.
She needs a Kiva loan of $1150 to increase her business.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Doris

texts.en: Kraban Support Foundation has trained Auntie Doris how to preserve fish through the TEACH lending programs. She sells fried fish in the community. She needs a Kiva loan of $650 to expand her fried fish business.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en: Josephine sells different kinds of threads and hair rollers in the community. She is a client of Kraban Support Foundation and has participated in the TEACH lending programs. She needs a Kiva loan of $800 to increase her business.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Esther

texts.en: Esther operates a provisions store and sells sauce pans as well. The TEACH lending program has improved her knowledge in trading through the Kraban Support Foundation. She needs a Kiva loan of $850 to expand her business.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en: Mercy sells a local beverage in the community. She has participated in the TEACH lending programs and is a member of Kraban Support Foundation. She needs a Kiva loan of $500 to expand her business and sell to school children.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Auntie Mary operates a "drinking spot" in her community. She sells many kinds of drinks in the spot. She has improved her business through the TEACH lending programs. Auntie Mary is a client of Kraban Support Foundation and needs a Kiva loan of $900 to buy more drinks for the store.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Johanna

texts.en:
Johanna tiene ya una experiencia de 6 años en el comercio. Ella trabajaba en un almacén de venta de electrodomésticos del cual salió ya que sus hijas quedaban al cuidado de otra persona. Todo esto lo hizo una vez separada del papá de las bebés el cual la dejó y ella con el dinero que había ahorrado y un préstamo que hizo logró ponerse un local de venta de comidas rápidas. Lo tiene funcionando desde hace 6 meses en el horario de 5 p.m. hasta las 12 p.m. y le ayuda su hermana.

Johanna desea el crédito para adecuar su hogar para el negocio ya que ahora ella se encuentra alquilando el local lo que le genera un egreso. También quiere ponerse un negocio de venta de colas en su domicilio. Su familia ya la está ayudando en la construcción del local y en un mes estará ya en su casa. También desea poner a disposición de sus clientes otra clase de platos para servirse.

Johanna tiene 27 años, es madre soltera de dos niñas, las cuales son el motivo para que ella haya salido adelante. Espera que con la inversión todo le vaya mejor y pueda comprarse un carrito de segunda para salir a comprar sus productos.

Translated from Spanish by Isabel Tan, a Kiva volunteer.

Johanna has 6 years of experience as a merchant. She used to work at store that sold electrical appliances, but she had to quit because her daughters were being left at the care of another person. She quit once she separated from the father of her daughters because he left her, and with the money she had saved and a loan, Johanna was able to set up a business to sell fast food. She has been running this business for 6 months now, and opens it from 5:00 pm to to 12:00 am. Her sister helps her.

Johanna wishes to get the loan so that she can adapt her home for the business since she is renting the place where it is located now, and that generates an extra expense. She also wants to set up a store to sell refreshments in her house. Her family is helping her build the new store and it will ready in a month. She also wishes to offer her clients other dishes.

Johanna is 27, she’s a single mom and has two girls. They are her driving force to continue in the struggle to get ahead. She hopes that with the investment, everything will be better and she’ll be able to buy a second-hand cart so she can go out and buy her products.

loans.use: Adecuar su hogar pare el negocio

loans.name: Rose

texts.en: Rose is a provisions store operator. She sells tinned and canned foods. She has been a client of Kraban Support Foundation for 3 years. Rose has participated in the TEACH lending programs and needs a Kiva loan of $850 to increase her corner shop business.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Vida

texts.en: Vida sells food called "fufu and soup". This kind of business is locally called a Chop Bar. She had her training from Kraban Support Foundation through the TEACH lending programs. She needs a Kiva loan of $850 to expand her chop bar business in the community.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Nancy

texts.en:
Nancy tiene una experiencia de 12 años en la venta de pescado ya que ella trabajaba con su mamá. Una vez que murió su madre tomó las riendas del negocio que lo ha logrado mantener por este tiempo en horario de 6 a.m. hasta las 2 p.m., en un mercado cerca de su domicilio.

Nancy desea el crédito para poder invertir una parte en su negocio y la otra volver a lo que ella hacía antes que era vender prendas de vestir, negocio que tuvo que dejarlo por falta de capital, deseando combinar estas dos actividades.

Nancy tiene 37 años, es separada hace 6 años, madre de 4 niños los que actualmente están estudiando pero ya el mayor de 16 años le ayuda en su negocio. Desea a futuro con su negocio y el ingreso que éste genere poder comprarse su casita propia ya que actualmente ella vive alquilando.

Translated from Spanish by Isabel Tan, a Kiva volunteer.

Nancy has 12 years of experience selling fish since she started working with her mother. After her mother died, Nancy took over the business and has been able to keep it. Her business sis open from 6:00 am to 2:00 pm at a market near her home.

Nancy would like to have the loan so she can invest a part of it in her business and the other part in her previous activity, which was to sell clothing. She had to leave the clothing business because she didn’t have enough capital. She now wishes to combine these two activities.

Nancy is 37, she has been separated for 6 years and has 4 children who are currently in school. The oldest son is already 16 and helps her with the business. In the future, with the income from her business, she would like to buy her own house since the one she’s living in right now is rented.

loans.use: Comprar mariscos al por mayor y tratar de entrar en la ventas de prendas otra vez

loans.name: Teresa

texts.en:
Teresa tiene una experiencia de 20 años en la venta de legumbres porque desde muy joven trabajaba junto a su mamá en las ferias libres. Poco a poco fue haciendo su capital con el cual puso su propio negocio que le ayuda a solventar los gastos de su hogar y darle una buena educación a sus hijos. Atiende el negocio en horario de 6 a.m. hasta las 2 p.m. todos los días de la semana junto a su esposo que la ayuda bastante.

Teresa desea el crédito para poder invertir en lo que tiene que ver a granos ya que por el momento no tiene esos productos. Además aspira poner en su domicilio un negocio de venta de colas para poderlo trabajar después de las 2 p.m. Teresa tiene 47 años, tiene 2 hijos los cuales ya son adultos y le ayudan en lo que mas puedan a su madre. Su esposo trabaja de albañil y los días que tiene libre le ayuda a Teresa en el negocio. Esperan poder terminar su casita la que actualmente es de caña.

Translated from Spanish by Isabel Tan, a Kiva volunteer.

Teresa has 20 years of experience selling vegetables because she started working with her mom since she was very young at the markets. Little by little, she was able to open her own business, which helps her make ends meet and provide a good education for her children. Teresa and her husband, who has been a great support, open the business everyday from 6:00 am to 2:00 pm.

Teresa would like to have the loan so that she can invest in grains, since she is currently not offering those products. Also, she would like to put up a store to sell refreshments and work at it after 2:00 pm.

Teresa is 47 years old. She has 2 sons who are already adults and help her as much as they can. Her husband works as a construction worker and helps her with the business whenever he has free time. They hope they can finish building their house, which is currently made out of cane.

loans.use: Invertir en productos de granos

loans.name: Akweso

texts.en: Kraban Support Foundation has helped Akweso to improve her beauty salon by using good-quality hair products for her customers. She had this training through TEACH lending programs. Akweso needs a Kiva loan of $850 to expand her business.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Helen

texts.en: Auntie Helen sells utensils within the community of Pantang in the Ga East District. She is a client of Kraban Support Foundation and has had training through TEACH lending programs. She needs a Kiva loan of $800 to expand her business.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Luz

texts.en:
Luz tiene una experiencia de 10 años en el negocio, actividad que la inició trabajando con su hermana en la venta de legumbres. Luego logró tener su propio capital y de esta manera su propio negocio el que lo logró ubicar en una feria libre cerca de su domicilio. Ya hace 5 años trabajándolo todos los días en horario de 6 a.m. hasta las 2 p.m.

Luz desea el crédito para poder invertirlo en su negocio, el que actualmente está un poco bajo de capital, esperando poder surtirlo y de esta manera poder obtener mejores ingresos.

Luz es viuda, tiene 48 años y 2 hijos los que actualmente viven con ella brindándole todo el apoyo que necesita. Espera poder volver también a la venta de fritada labor que la realizaba por las tardes luego de terminada su jornada en el mercado, y que la dejó por falta de capital.

Translated from Spanish by Isabel Tan, a Kiva volunteer.

Luz has 10 years of experience in her business, which she started by working with her sister selling vegetables. She later managed to have her own capital, and with it she opened her own business at a market near her house. Luz has had her business for 5 years and opens it everyday from 6:00 am to 2:00 pm.

Luz would like to get the loan so she can invest it in her business, which is currently lacking a bit of capital. With the loan she’d be able to have more supplies for her store and thus have more income.

Luz is a widow, she is 48 and has 2 sons who give her all the support she needs. She would like to sell fried food again, just as she used to do in the afternoons after working at the market. She stopped selling fried food because she didn’t have enough capital.

loans.use: Comprar mas legumbres al por mayor

loans.name: Filiata

texts.en: Filiata is 48 years old, married and has five children. She joined the program in 2004, and her husband and two of their sons have since then been doing taro farming. She sells the produce, including not only taro but also bananas and other vegetables, in the central market in Apia three times a week. Expanding her farm will enbale Filiata to improve her house and send her little children to school.

loans.use: To purchase organic fertilizers, fungicides, and pesticides

loans.name: Malu

texts.en: Malu, 35, married, joined the SPBD microcredit programme in 2005, although she started her fishing business already five years ago. Her husband and two other boys from the same village are also involved in the business; however, Malu is the one who sells fish at the Savalalo Fish Market. Her last loan helped her very much - she was able to purchase a deep freezer and two gallons of coolers. With the help of an additional loan, she intends to buy more coolers to store more fish.

loans.use: To purchase four (4) additional coolers for storing fish.

loans.name: Teresa

texts.en:
Teresa tiene una experiencia de 12 años en su negocio el cual junto a su esposo lo iniciaron una vez venido del campo en donde vendieron la propiedad que tenía. Con ese dinero lograron poner una tienda la cual tuvieron que cerrar por fuerzas mayores. En ese momento con el esfuerzo y lucha lograron financiarse y pusieron un depósito de gas, motivo ya que en el sector no lo había. Han logrado mantener trabajando todos los días de la semana en horario de 6 a.m. hasta las 10 p.m. Ella trabaja en el local y su esposo sale en un triciclo a vender por el sector.

Teresa desea el crédito para poder reiniciar el negocio de ferretería, que se encuentra en el mismo local de venta de gas, dándole una mejor imagen al negocio. Teresa es casada, tiene 62 años y 11 hijos los que ya son adultos y siempre están pendientes de ella, esperando poder mejorar su casita y poder vivir mejor junto a su esposo.

Translated from Spanish by Isabel Tan, a Kiva volunteer.

Teresa has 12 years of experience in her business, which she established with her husband once they came from the countryside, where they sold the property they had. With the money, they were able to open a store which they had to close due to circumstances beyond their control. At that moment, with their effort and perseverance they were able to open a store to sell containers of gas, since the area they were located didn’t have one. They open the store seven days a week from 6:00 am to 10:00 pm. Teresa works at the store while her husband rides the tricycle to offer the gas containers around the area.

Teresa would like to have the loan so she can restart the hardware store that they had at the same place where they are now selling containers of gas. This would help improve the image of their business. Teresa is 62 and married with 11 children which are all adults already and are always taking care of her. She would like to improve her house and live a better quality of life with her husband.

loans.use: Vender ferreteria y tambien gas

loans.name: Luisa

texts.en:
Luisa's store sits on top of a hill overlooking her barrio of El Progreso. Community members take a short trek from their homes below to buy day-to-day necessities from Luisa's shop such as canned food, beverages, fresh vegetables and bread. She is prepared to expand her business that not only supports her neighbors, but provides income to care for her three children, ages 11, 9 and 8, whom she raises with her husband, Gregorio. Luisa's request for a loan is to add poultry and dairy products to her menu.

Geographic isolation and poor transportation options make Luisa's a convenient and necessary part of this impoverished community in the Los Alcarrizos region of this Caribbean country. Luisa has vocational training in commerce and continual support by her loan officer, Rebeca Almanzar Rosa. Her son and two daughters are able to go attend school rather than taking odd-jobs to help the family make a living. Their mother has the means to take care of them and with this new loan, their income will increase as she work her way out of poverty.

NOTE: Luisa is a member of the "La Triunfadora" group, along with four other entrepreneurs. They will be accountable to one another for paying back their loan of $750. This group lending method requires group members to help one another throughout the loan repayment process. Loans are paid back as a group. If one person is deficient on their loan, the group must make up the difference. Everyone in Luisa's group has gone through Esperanza's training and demonstrated to be responsible and determined.

loans.use: Purchase poultry, beans, cheese and additional goods for her store.

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Helen

texts.en: Unlike most women in her village, Helen managed to gain financial independence from her husband. She achieved this by joining the SPBD microcredit programme.  She started her business with just a small shop, but, with the help of a small loan, Helen has been able to buy more fabrics and a sewing machine.

loans.use: To purchase more sewing machines

loans.name: Mohammad Saleem

texts.en:
M. Saleem was born in 1972 and lives in a household of four in district 3 of Kabul, Afghanistan.

M. Saleem has already finished a group loan and has now taken his first individual loan. Before, he had a small business selling fuel, then he took a loan through AFSG to buy more fuel and make a cart for himself. 

M. Saleem is an educated man, but due to a lack of income in the family he left his government job. Now he is making more money and is thus able to solve his family problems.

loans.use: Buying fuel

loans.name: Ab.rahman

texts.en:
Ab. Rahman was born in 1979 and lives in a  household of 6 in district 5 of Kabul, Afghanistan.

Ab.Rahman has 3 years' experince in selling gas. At the start he had one gas balloon, then he took a loan from AFSG and bought several balloons and carts to increase his business and cover his family expenses.

Ab.Rahman studied up to the 10th grade, but then he had to leave to make money. He is a good sales person. He sells 70 kilos of gas per day. He believes that by being a good client of AFSG he can take more another loan to get a shop and increase his business.

loans.use: Buying fuel, gas

loans.name: Khanum Gul

texts.en:
Khanum Gul is 44 years old and lives in a household of 15 in district 5 Kabul Afghanistan

Khanum Gul lost her husband during the war. She is living with her sons who are selling mobile cards in the bazaar. Her first two sons have a mobile shop in the market and the 3rd one, whom Khanum Gul took out the loan for, sells in the street. 

With the help of neighbours, Khanum Gul took a 1st cycle loan for her son. She hopes to repay her installments of her 1st cycle loan so she can take more loans and cover the family financially.

loans.use: To buy mobile cards

loans.name: Wajia

texts.en:
Wajia is a client of AFSG. Born in 1982, married with Mobin and with 3 children, she now lives in district 5 of Kabul, Afghanistan.
 
She took a loan for her husband's general store to support her family's financial situation. AFSG granted her a loan which her husband used for purchasing required materials such as rice, beans, tea, sugar, etc. for his general store.

loans.use: To buy goods like rice, ghee, tea, sugar, etc.

loans.name: Syed Saki

texts.en:
Sayed Saki was born in 1970 and lives in a household of 11 in district 5 of Kabul, Afghanistan.

He took a loan for his general store to support his family financially and buys lots of materials for his shop. AFSG granted his loan, which he used for purchasing required materials such as rice, beans, tea, sugar, etc.

Saki has almost completed his 3rd cycle loan and continues with a 4th cycle loan to rebuild his shop and buy materials.

loans.use: To buy ghee, rice, peas, beans, tea, sugar...etc.

loans.name: Mukaddas

texts.en:
Mukaddas A. is a successful woman with interesting family roots. She is a granddaughter of the famous national hero – Mastura Avezova. Mastura Avezova is a first lady who took off the “burka” (a cloth covering a woman’s face) in the early years of 20th century in Tajikistan. She worked at the silk factory and attracted the other women to take off the burka and to become active member of the society. So her granddaughter Mukaddas A.  from childhood used to work, earn money and be independent woman. 
Last year she received a loan for her hairdressing salon. As a result this salon became very active and now four hairdressers work there. The last loan she received was for accessories and a sewing bench in her sewing shop. There are two dressmakers in her sewing shop. Last year she organized a national dresses and suits demonstration in honor of her grandmother. After this demonstration she doubled the number of her clients. Now she has a plan to organize such demonstrations periodically to increase the volume of her shop, to provide more workplaces and to develop local production.

loans.use: Materials for Spring Season

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Ilkhom

texts.en: S. Ilkhom is 31 years old and is married with two sons. He has a University degree and is very proud of that. He has studied at the faculty of finance and credit. His dream was always to work in a bank. But it is complicated to find a high payable job in Tajikistan, especially in rural regions. Ilkhom decided to use his own vehicle as a taxi. His vehicle was old and always was out for maintenance. He had the skills for maintenance but the spare parts were expensive and he did not have enough funds. That is why he applied to MicroInvest for his first loan. After receiving his loan he repaired his own vehicle and helped some other people he knew in repairing their vehicles. By now he became a very good repairman and number of his clients have increased. His business is going well but he feels bad that couldn’t use his education. Now beside maintenance, he would like to receive a loan to open a shop of spare parts for the vehicles. This will be a good chance to use his theoretical knowledge in practice.

loans.use: Purchasing automobile spare parts

loans.name: Racim

texts.en:
Racim was born in 1979 in Gubadli. He is an internally displaced person (IDP). Racim, with his family, settled in Sumgait city. After military service he could not continue his education because the family condition was very heavy. He is 27 years old. Racim has rented a very small place near the Dental Clinic and has been busy preparing false teeth. He does not have enough funds and he wants first loan from KIVA, to develop his business well enough.

He is applying for the $1200 loan to expand his business.

loans.use: To expand his business and buy dental instruments.

loans.name: Aladdin

texts.en: Aladdin is an IDP from occupied Fizuli district of Azerbaijan. He fled to Baku in 1993 and opened his business in 2001. He is married and has a child. His first loan he planned to take from Normicro Baku branch, he wants to use to buy new equipment for the business.

loans.use: To buy some new equipment to serve clients with better quality

loans.name: Khagani

texts.en: Khagani is an IDP from occupied Fizulir district of Azerbaijan. He fled to Baku in 1993. He is married and has two children. He started his business in 2000, and borrowed five Normicro loans from Baku branch for a total of $3800. Now he would like to borrow $1200.

loans.use: To expand volume of business

loans.name: Rashid

texts.en: Rashid is an IDP from occupied Khodjali district of Azerbaijan. He fled to Baku in 1993. Married, has two children. He started his business in 1993, and borrowed five Normicro loans from Baku branch totaling $1700 totaling. Now he would like to borrow $500.

loans.use: To buy new equipment

loans.name: Gusdasta

texts.en: Gusdasta is an IDP from occupied Khodjali district of Azerbaijan. She fled to Baku in 1993. Married, has two children. She started her business in 1995, and borrowed three Normicro loans from Baku branch totalling $2200. Now she would like to borrow $600.

loans.use: To increase variety of goods

loans.name: Khagani

texts.en: Khagani is an IDP from occupied Zangilan district of Azerbaijan. He fled to Baku in 1993. He started his business in 2006, and borrowed two Normicro loans from Baku branch totalling $900. Now he is willing to borrow $300.

loans.use: To buy new computer for his salon

loans.name: Ismail Mamedov

texts.en: Ismail is an IDP from occupied Jebrail district of Azerbaijan. He fled to Baku in 1993. Married, has three children. He started his business in 1996, and borrowed four Normicro loans from Baku branch totalling $2200. Now he is willing to borrow $500.

loans.use: To increase variety of goods

loans.name: Arif

texts.en: Arif is an IDP from occupied Khodjali district of Azerbaijan. He fled to Baku in 1993. Married, has three children. He started his business in 2002, and borrowed two Normicro loans from Baku branch totalling $1350. Now he would like to borrow $850.

loans.use: To expand volume of business

loans.name: Minaye

texts.en: Minaye is an IDP from occupied Fizuli district of Azerbaijan. She fled to Baku in 1993. She is married and has three children. She started her business in 1997, and borrowed two Normicro loans from Baku branch totaling $1400. Now she would like to borrow $1000.

loans.use: To increase variety of goods

loans.name: Metanet

texts.en: Metanet is an IDP from occupied Agdam district of Azerbaijan. She fled to Baku in 1993. She is married and has two children. She started her business in 1995, and borrowed two Normicro loans from Baku branch totaling $1400. Now she would like to borrow $500.

loans.use: To increase variety of goods

loans.name: Nasiba

texts.en: Nasiba E. lives and runs a small retail business in Aghsu city where she sells fruits and vegetables. She is a 59-year-old widow of four children. Nasiba wants to expand her inventory to provide other food and household items for her customers.

loans.use: purchase more inventory

loans.name: Rafig

texts.en: Rafig G. lives and runs a barbershop by the bazaar in Aghsu city. He has been running his own barbershop for almost 12 years. Rafig is married, living with his two children and their families. One of his sons was killed 14 years ago during the war. Rafig hopes to expand his business by purchasing a new location and eventually opening a women's salon.

loans.use: To purchase a larger barbershop and open a women's salon

loans.name: Liza

texts.en: Liza I. lives in Aghsu city where she owns a small furniture store. She is 56 years old. She is a widow with three children. Liza has owned her small business for the last nine years. With this loan she wants to expand her inventory and provide her customers with more selection.

loans.use: purchase more inventory for her store

loans.name: Hameda

texts.en:
Hameda was born in 1974 and is a mother of 4 children. They live in district 5 of Kabul, Afghanistan. 

Hameda took a loan for her husband to re-build his shop and buys lots of goods for it so he can support his family financially. AFSG granted his loan which he used for purchasing required materials such as rice, beans, tea, sugar, etc.  


Hameda does not have an education but she has six years' experience in the handicraft business.

loans.use: To buy ghee, rice, tea, etc.

loans.name: Farhad

texts.en: Farhad M. runs a small metal works shop in Aghsu city and is being trained in the family trade of ironworks by his father, along with his brother, Terlan. He opened his own metal shop five years ago making and repairing, by hand, knives, saws, shovels and other iron items. With this loan Farhad wants to purchase more raw materials for his shop and begin to repair and manufacture other items, such as carburetors for vehicles.

loans.use: Needs to purchase more raw materials for his shop

loans.name: Terbiye

texts.en:
Terbiye has been in this business for 20 years.
This 57-year-old woman lives in Yenikand village, Salyan region. She is married and has 4 children.
She requests a loan of $1000 to buy 4 pregnant cows.
Terbiye plans to increase the number of cows and to start producing milk which she will take to the market.

loans.use: To buy 4 pregnant cows

loans.name: Jeyhun

texts.en: Jeyhun M. owns a home electronics store in the small town of Devechi, located just south of Khachmaz in the North Eastern part of Azerbaijan. Jeyhun is looking for funding so that he can add shelving and increase the inventory of his store. He knows that he will attract more customers when his store has more to offer.

loans.use: To add shelving and inventory to his store

loans.name: Terlan

texts.en: Terlan M. lives and owns a small metal shop in Aghsu city. He is married with two children. Terlan, along with his brother Farhad, were trained in the family trade of ironworks by their father. He has run his own shop for the past eight years making knives, saws, shovels, and other metal items. Terlan wants to use this loan to buy more raw materials.

loans.use: to purchase more raw materials

loans.name: Elchin

texts.en:
Elchin is a 44 year old Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan, Kalbadjar  region,who has settled in Khirdalan settlement. He is  married and has 3 children.
Having borrowed $400, he bought spare parts for all types of cars to meet his customer’s needs. He has his own machine shop. He has been in this business for 4 years. 
Now he needs a loan to do capital repairs to his own shop.

loans.use: To do capital repairs to his own shop

loans.name: Vali

texts.en: Vali M. lives in Aghsu city where he owns and operates a water truck. He transports and sells water from the mountains of Aghsu and Shamakha to the residents of Aghsu city and the surrounding villages in the Aghsu region. Vali is married with two children. With this loan he wants to change out his vehicle's engine from benzine to diesel, making his truck more cost efficient to operate.

loans.use: to change out his vehicle engine

loans.name: Qahir

texts.en: Qahir M. lives in Aghsu city with his wife and two children. He opened up his tea shop 13 years ago. Tea houses in Azerbaijan are very important to the culture, its a place where men can congregate and discuss current events and play the traditional game of nard, or backgammon. Qahir wants to remodel and enlarge his tea shop as well as purchase new glassware and dishes.

loans.use: Remodel and repair inside of tea house as well as purchase new glassware

loans.name: Tarana

texts.en: Tarana O. lives in Aghsu city where she has owned a small pharmacy for the past 10 years. She is single, but supports her mother and father. Tarana wants to expand her inventory and needs to purchase more pharmaceutical supplies and items for her store.

loans.use: To purchase more pharmaceutical supplies and items

loans.name: Azar

texts.en: Azar S. lives in Aghsu where he owns a small retail store. He sells food, cleaning items, personal hygeine, as well as various other items. Azar is married with two children. Currently his store is attached to his house and with this loan he wants to build a larger location separate from his home.

loans.use: To build a larger location separate from his residence

loans.name: Hasanaga

texts.en:
Hasanaga owns a furniture store in the small town of Devechi, just south of Khachmaz, located in the North Easter part of Azerbaijan. Hasanaga wants to invest in a greater variety of furniture for an increasing customer base.
His store is a family business and his whife (Malahat Kazimova), who also received loan from Normicro Baku branch, uses this fund in the same furniture store. Together they need 2350$ to buy new inventories for the store. Hasanaga applies for the half of that amount.

loans.use: To increase variety of furniture in his store

loans.name: Juma

texts.en: Juma is a farmer. He has a big family. The last ten years he lived with his family in Russia. There he had a farm with bulls and poultry. These last years the conditions for working migrants became very difficult and he decided to come back to his motherland. Juma has come to Tajikistan  alone for now. His family is still in Russia. He would like to continue the activity he knows best – livestock breeding. It’s very important for him for and his family. He is sure that he can use the loan with success, to increase his activity and to bring his family back home.

loans.use: Livestock breeding

payments.comment:
Two repayments were incorrectly posted on April 18th, 2007.

The Kiva Staff

loans.name: Eldaniz

texts.en: Eladaniz S. lives in Aghsu city where he owns a small tire shop. He has been selling and repairing tires for the past eight years. Eldaniz is married with two children. With this loan he wants to purchase more tires and other items for his shop.

loans.use: To purchase more inventory

loans.name: Malahat

texts.en: Malahat K. owns a furniture store in the small town of Devechi, just south of Khachmaz, located in the North Eastern part of Azerbaijan. Malahat is looking for funding so that she can increase the quantity and quality of her inventory. Her small town is growing and people need to furnish their homes. Her business is family business and she runs the store with her husband Hasanaga Kazimov who also received loan from Normicro Baku branch and used it in the same store. Together they need 2350$ to buy new inventories for the store. Hasanaga applies for the half of that amount.

loans.use: To increase quantity and quality of her inventory

loans.name: Rahim

texts.en: Rahim V. lives in Aghsu city where he owns and operates a small store that sells mobile phones and mobile phone accessories. He is married with one child. He has owned this store for the past eight years. With this loan Rahim wants to expand his inventory and purchase more mobile phones and accessories.

loans.use: Purchase more inventory

loans.name: Mukhtaram

texts.en: Mukhtaram V. is a divorced woman who has three children (2 daughters and 1 son). She worked at home as a dressmaker. She had very few clients, due to small choice of materials and accessories. She did not have enough capital to buy those and as a result her profit was too small to make a living. Therefore she had to leave her children with her mother and go to work in Russia. She worked there one month and came back because could not stay separately from her children. When she came back she joined the group of clients who received loans from MicroInvest. She spent the first loan for materials and accessories. Now she would like to rent a shop to sew dresses and sell them at the market on weekends.

loans.use: Sewing national dresses

loans.name: Kubra

texts.en: Kubra A. works out of her home making hand-made carpets in the small town of Devechi, which is just south of Khachmaz. She is looking for funding so that she can purchase more supplies and hire another worker to increase productivity. It takes a long time to make a carpet by hand and she has more requests then she can currently handle.

loans.use: To hire another employee and to purchase more supplies

loans.name: Galib

texts.en:
Galib lives in Yenikand village, Salyan region  He is 42, married, has 2 children.  
He needs a loan of $1000 to buy a water heater for his hair dressing salon.
Galib has a strong belief that he will get more clients after purchasing all the equipment needed for a modern salon and this will lead to increased income.He has worked in this salon for 4 years.
This business has allowed him to provide a good source of income for his family .
He made an a strong effort to improve his services.
His salon attracts regular clients.

loans.use: To buy a water heater

loans.name: Muyassar

texts.en: Muyassar is engaged in retail trade of clothes. She is a widow. She has raised her son herself without help from others. Muyassar is one of the first clients of our organization She is thankful to MicroInvest because with her previous loans she was able to develop her business and with the income help to her son to graduate from University. Now her son is a teacher of history at University. Currently Muyassar lives in a two-rooms apartment together with her son, his wife and their two daughters. Her son is working on his doctoral thesis. It is complicated to work in same room. That is why Muyassar would like to expand her business and use obtained profit for purchasing another apartment. Besides, for successful completion of doctoral thesis of her son it’s necessary certain amount of money. The salary of the teachers in our country is not high, and her son has to use his salary for his historical science work.  Muyassar carries  all the other expenses of their family. She will use her loan to increase volume of assets and try to buy goods at wholesale price.

loans.use: Retail trade of clothing

loans.name: Elshan

texts.en: Elshan Z. lives in Aghsu city where he owns a small welding shop. He is married with three children. Elshan has owned his own shop for 18 years. At his shop he handles many different kinds of things including the welding of gates, terraces, and pipes. With this loan he wants to purchase new equipment.

loans.use: To purchase new equipment

loans.name: Asli

texts.en: Asli G. owns a small market in the small town of Devechi, just south of Khachmaz, located in the North Eastern part of Azerbaijan. Asli is looking for funding so that she can increase the diversity of her inventory as well as make some minor repairs to her store.

loans.use: To increase the diversity of her inventory

loans.name: Alikram

texts.en: Alikram B. is a mechanic in the small town of Devechi, just south of Khachmaz, located in the North Eastern part of Azerbaijan. Alikram wants to invest in newer tools so that he can perform difficult jobs more efficiently. This will allow him to increase his work load and, therefore, his income.

loans.use: To invest in newer tools so that he can perform difficult jobs more efficiently.

loans.name: Gavkhar

texts.en: Several years ago Gavhar was a famous theatre dancer in Tajikistan. This beautiful woman many times has fascinated people with her skills of dance and acting. During a civil war in the early 90’s in Tajikistan, she and her two daughters went to Moscow.  They worked for over 8 years there at local market and then came back to Tajikistan. With the savings that she made while being in Russia Gavhar decided to start her own business. For the last three years she has been delivering and distributing spare parts from Bishkek to Tajikistan. Gavhar has had a very difficult life but she is an optimist. Recently she purchased a flat and has a plan to reequip it into a shop. That’s why she needs additional capital. The main goal for her is to make as much profit as she can in order to help her two daughters, nine grandchildren and one great-granddaughter.

loans.use: Retail trade (spare parts)

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Rahila

texts.en: Rahila H. (her husband is pictured) owns a small market in the small town of Devechi, just south of Khachmaz, located in the North Eastern part of Azerbaijan. Rahila is looking for funding so that she can increase the quantity and quality of her inventory.

loans.use: To increase the quanity and qulity of her inventory.

loans.name: Vitalyi

texts.en:
Vitalyi is happily married with two sons. After the collapse of the Soviet Union, Vitalyi had a hard time finding a job. In 1992 he decided to start his own small business selling video tapes which was quite popular in post-Soviet Ukraine at the time. His persistence and determination helped him stay in the saddle through tough economic times. Later, Vitalyi decided to change his area of business and began selling office supplies. This business has been the only source of income for his family since the late 1990’s. Currently, Vitalyi sees about $800 in net profit every month. Vitalyi is very responsible. He has promptly repaid all loans he has received from “Nadiya Ukraine”. Financial assistance has not only helped him to grow his business selling CDs, notebooks, greeting cards, paper, markers, and children’s literature, but it has also enabled him to expand into a new area. Recently Vitalyi opened a new store selling household chemical items in one of the local malls in Berdyansk. He would like to get a loan of $1,200 to increase his inventory of household chemical products in the second store. He is planning to purchase a variety of laundry soaps, shampoos, cleaners, solvent-free furniture polish, air fresheners and other consumer products. The loan will give Vitalyi necessary capital to purchase this inventory and increase his sales and profits. Funds generated will allow him to continue to expand his business and will give him the opportunity to provide for and improve the living conditions for his family which he believes is his first priority in life.

Віталій - одружений, в нього двоє синів. Після розвалу Радянського Союзу Віталій довго не міг знайти роботу. В 1992 році він вирішив відкрити власну крамницю з продажу відеокасет, які користувалися широким попитом в пострадянській Україні. Торгівля була єдиним джерелом прибутку для його родини наприкінці 90-х років. Наполегливість та цілеспрямованість Віталія допомогли йому пережити важкі економічні часи. Пізніше він вирішив змінити напрямок бізнесу та почав торгувати канцтоварами. Зараз Віталій щомісяця заробляє приблизно 800 доларів чистого прибутку. Віталій – дуже відповідальний. Він вчасно сплатив усі позики, які отримав в „Надії України”. Фінансова підтримка сприяла збільшенню обсягів торгівлі компакт-дисками, зошитами, листівками, папером, маркерами та дитячою літературою. Окрім цього позики також допомогли йому відкрити нову крамницю з продажу побутової хімії на одному з місцевих ринків міста Бердянськ. Віталій хотів би отримати позику в 1200 доларів для того, щоб закупити побутову хімію для подальшої роздрібної торгівлі. Він планує купити різноманітні пральні порошки, шампуні, очищувачі повітря, поліроль для меблів, очищувальні засоби та іншу побутову хімію. Позика допоможе Віталію отримати необхідні кошти для того, щоб придбати ці товари та збільшити обсяги продажу, а отже, і власні прибутки. Зароблені кошти сприятимуть подальшому зростанню бізнесу Віталія, допоможуть йому покращити власні житлові умови та забезпечать головні потреби його родини, яка у Віталія завжди на першому місці.

loans.use: To increase inventory of household chemical products

loans.name: Hamdular

texts.en: Hamdular A. owns a small market in the small town of Devechi, just south of Khachmaz, located in the North Eastern part of Azerbaijan. Hamdular wants to remodel her store and increase the quantity and variety of her inventory.

loans.use: To remodel her store and to increase the diversity of her inventory

loans.name: Sergey

texts.en:
Sergey has a small business selling auto supplies. He offers a variety of products such as lubricating oil, anti-freeze, oil filters and spare parts. Sergey owns a small storefront in the auto market and rents a second vending facility in another part of the city. Convenient locations and bright advertising signs attract many potential customers to his stores. Presently, Sergey makes about $1,000 net profit per month. Sergey is hard-working and focused. He has invested a lot of energy, money and effort into his business. He is very flexible and closely follows trends in the fast changing auto business. This allows him to best serve his customers’ needs and helps to boost his sales. Sergey is also very optimistic and can handle challenging situations. Not long ago he underwent a serious surgery. However, he didn’t let it affect his business. On the contrary, strategic thinking and good decision making helped Sergey increase his sales and generate additional profit. Sergey is requesting a loan of $1,200 to increase his supply of lube oils and auto accessories. He would like to expand his business and is planning to hire more sales staff. This will provide a good income for one or two more families in the community. Sergey is a businessman who sets high goals and knows how to achieve them. We believe Sergey will continue to benefit from consistent financial support that will strengthen his business and provide an important means to realize his goals.

Сергій займається продажем автозапчастин, а саме: мастил, антифризу, фільтрів тощо. Сергій – власник кіоску на місцевому авторинку. Він також орендує ще одне торгівельне приміщення в іншій частині міста. Зручне розташування та яскраві рекламні щити приваблюють багато потенційних покупців до його торгівельних кіосків. Зараз Сергій заробляє приблизно 1000 доларів чистого прибутку щомісяця. Сергій – працьовитий та цілеспрямований. Він вклав багато сил, грошей та зусиль в розвиток свого бізнесу. Він дуже гнучкий, пильно слідкує за усіма змінними тенденціями в автобізнесі. Це допомагає йому якнайкраще обслуговувати клієнтів та постійно збільшувати обсяги продажів. Сергій – дуже оптимістичний, він з легкістю долає перешкоди. Нещодавно він переніс серйозну операцію. Однак, це не вплинуло на його бізнес. Навпаки, стратегічне мислення та вміння вчасно приймати правильні рішення допомогли Сергію розширити торгівлю та отримати додатковий прибуток. Сергій просить про позику в 1200 доларів для того, щоб придбати мастила та автоаксесуари. Він хотів би розширити власний бізнес та взяти на роботу ще двох реалі заторів, що в свою чергу забезпечить стабільний заробіток для ще двох родин. Сергій – підприємець, який вміє досягати власної мети. Він неодмінно використає отриману фінансову підтримку для того, щоб розширити власний бізнес та виконати поставлені перед собою цілі.

loans.use: To purchase assorted oils, filters, antifreeze

loans.name: Gelem

texts.en:
This 44-year-old woman is  very active and responsible. 6 years ago she decided to start her own business. 
Gelem is highly educated. She is a physics teacher.  She is an  Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan, Kalbadjar region, settled in the Absheron region. She is divorced with no children. She deals with computers for typesetting documents of clients.
Gelem started her business from her personal savings from her teaching position. She managed to save capital for the opening of her business.
Now she wants to expand it and add more computers and stationary to avoid  shortages which always inconvenience her customers.
With credits that she received and successfully paid back, she opened a small service center.
Gelem needs a loan of $1200 to buy some new office furniture and a  new computer.
With this business she can obtain an income to cover all her family necessities.

loans.use: To buy new office furniture and a  new computer

loans.name: Murad

texts.en:
35-year-old Murad with his 1 child settled in Sumgait city. He is an internally displaced person (IDP) from the Zangilan region. Since 2004 he has been engaged in meat sales to improve his family’s living condition. As he did not have enough funds, he could not develop his business well enough in the beginning. Having borrowed first loans of amount $800 he significantly expanded his business, has built the new cold store. The loans were paid back timely.
Now Murad wants loan amount of $1200 for construction of his own butcher shop.

loans.use: To construct his own butcher shop

loans.name: Ramziyya

texts.en: Ramziyya is Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-ocupied territory of Azerbaijan Jabrail region, settled in Sumgait city. She has 2 children. This 23-year-old woman has been engaged in her business for 2 years. Ramziyya sells women’s clothes. She supports her family with this business. Now Ramziyya needs a loan amount of $1100 to be busy with selling the clothing.

loans.use: To be busy with selling clothing

loans.name: Anar

texts.en:
Anar is a very active and responsible man.
8 years ago he decided to start a small business. This business has allowed his family to have a better income.
Having borrowed $400 he bought foodstuffs.
Now he needs a loan of $700 to expand the area of his store. 
Anar is 29 years old. He is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan, Shusha town, settled in Khaladj village, Salyan region. Anar is single.

loans.use: To expand the area of his store

loans.name: Shirkhan

texts.en:
Shirkhan is a very kind, friendly and hard-working person. He has had his business for 20 years ago and it allows him to support his family. His efforts have led him to achieve what he has today.
Each day he works harder to grow.
In the beginning of his business he borrowed $400 and bought 7 pregnant sheep.
The second time he borrowed $700 and bought 12 pregnant sheep.
Now he needs a loan of $1000 to buy 20 pedigree ewes.
56-year-old Shirkhan is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan, Fizuli region, settled in Khaladj village, Salyan region. He is married and has 7 children.

loans.use: To buy 20 pedigree ewes

loans.name: Nasreen

texts.en:
Nasreen is married and lives in a household of nine in Kabul, Afghanistan. 

She has a shared business with her husband, who has five years' experience from his bakery shop. He bakes and then sells bread in the bazaar. Due to a lack of material she took a loan so they can buy wood, flour, etc. 

She prepares the yeast for her husband, then he bakes the bread and sells it at the bazaar. She is very happy to support her family through this business.

loans.use: Buying wood, flour, etc.

loans.name: Irada

texts.en:
Irada has 4 hectare plot of land. She plans to buy 100 kilogramms of clover seed to grow clover. Irada also breeds cows and wants to buy 2 cows. 
Irada has run this business for 15 years. She lives in Salyan region Yenikand village. She is married, has 4 children.
Now she needs a loan of $1000 to bring about her plans. 
With this business she will meet the needs of her family.

loans.use: To buy clover seed and 2 cows

loans.name: Noor Agha

texts.en:
Noor Agha has a fuel and gas cart. He is 44 years old, married, and lives in a family of 8 in district 5 of Kabul, Afghanistan.

He went through a bad patch during the war, but then he decided to take a loan to support him through his business, so he took a loan from AFSG and bought gas balloons and fuel so he could cover his family financially. Now he sells 90 kilos of gas per day.

loans.use: To buy fuel, gas, etc.

loans.name: Telman

texts.en:
Telman is 57 years old. He is married and has 2 children. He lives in Khaladj village,Salyan region. 
He has run this business for 4 years. He has received several loans to expand his farming.
Now he needs a loan of $1000 to buy fertilizer.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer

loans.name: Teymur

texts.en:
Teymur is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan, Lachin region, settled in Khaladj village,Salyan region. He is married and has a child.
He has run this business for 2 years. He has his own shop. He needs a loan of $700 to expand the area of his shop.

loans.use: To expand the area of his shop

loans.name: Peace

texts.en: Auntie Peace lives in Adenta, a suburb of Accra, in the Greater Accra region of Ghana. This community has a population of about 30,000. She sells kenkey, a local dish, to school children and the public as a whole. She buys cartons of fish from the port and fries them to serve with her kenkey. Demand from her increase as the population increases. She is therefore seeking a loan of $900 from Kiva to enable her to cook in large quantities.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Bahar

texts.en:
Bahar was born in 1972 in Yenikand village, Salyan region. She is married and has 2 children. She has been a cattle breeder since 2004. She is a role model to many woman. 
She requests a loan of $800 to buy 2 pregnant calves She works hard for the success of her children. She wants to improve her business and her revenue, which will result in better living conditions for her family.

loans.use: To buy 2 pregnant calves

loans.name: Ayisha

texts.en: Ayisha is 40 years old and a mother of 4. She resides at Effiakuma where she runs a small food joint. She has done this business for the past 2 years. There seems to be considerable progress with adequate potential for growth. Ayi has also gone through the TEACH sessions of Kraban Support Foundation. Equipped with these skills she is seeking this loan from Kiva in order to expand her business.

loans.use: Capital

loans.name: Vida

texts.en: Vida is a 35 year-old woman who lives in Adenta, a suburb of Accra, Ghana. She sells textiles from factories and ready-made dresses from one place to the other. She walks a long distance to sell her items. She wishes to have her own shop where she can sell her goods. She is seeking a loan of $900 from Kiva to help her open her own shop.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Adelaide

texts.en: D.'s Bakery serves the public with different kinds of breads such as brown bread, sugar bread, butter bread, tea bread and many more. The baker, Miss Adlaide D., has her own oven but has no capital to buy flour in bags and margarine for baking. She is seeking a loan of $950 from Kiva. She is hardworking and capable of paying it back.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Augustina

texts.en: Sister Tina, as she is called by her customers, sells carrier bags made of rubber. She buys from the company in bulk and retails to her customers at moderate prices. She has a lot of customers and so she sells her bags very fast. Recently, when interviewed about the sudden fall in her sales, she said, "I have no money to buy from the producing company since prices have gone higher than expected." She needs help and is seeking a loan of $750 from Kiva to enable her to buy direct from the company.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Rukaya

texts.en: Rukaya is 38 years old. She is married with 3 children. She runs a major food joint at Effiakuma, a suburb of Takoradi. She has been providing local foods to the community for the last 3 years. These include rice, rice balls and banku, which is made from corn. She has gone through the TEACH sessions of Kraban Support Foundation. She therefore wants Kiva to assist her with the loan to acquire a permanent structure to grow the business and give comfort to customers in a clean environment.

loans.use: Capital

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of an energy saving meko (cooking stove)

loans.name: Charity

texts.en: Madam Charity sells textiles of various kinds. She buys direct from textile factories and retails to her customers. A lot of people patronize her shop due to the moderate price of her goods, but of late she is loosing her customers to other retailers because her customers cannot get the kind of clothes they want from her shop. She stopped buying from the company because she has no money. She is seeking a loan of $1100 from Kiva to enable her buy direct from the company to supply her customers.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Bertha

texts.en: Bertha lives in Abokobi, a suburb of Accra, Ghana. She has 4 children of school-going age. She sells various items such as candies, milk, milo, soaps, carrier bags, etc. She owns a table-top shop and wants to expand it. She is seeking a loan of $750 from Kiva to enable her carry out the expansion.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Auntie Grace is the owner of Enidaso Woho Cold Store. She sells frozen foods such as chicken, beef, pork and fish of different kinds. She buys direct from farms and the harbour. She used to buy in cartons for her shop but she stopped because she has no deep freezer to enable her buy in bulk and store the food. She needs deep freezers and is seeking a loan of $1000 from Kiva to enable her buy these freezers.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Vida

texts.en: Madame Vida sells wakye, a local meal prepared from a special rice and beans and served with stew. She buys her rice and beans direct from the producers in bags. A lot of people enjoy her meals and she has a large number of people who buy from her. She wants to open a mini-restaurant where she can add other local dishes to her meals. She is seeking a loan of $800 from Kiva to help her realise this dream.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Beauty

texts.en: Auntie B, as she is called in her community, sells a variety of goods from a table-top. Her sales are expanding and she wishes to open a mini-supermarket where she can sell her goods but she has no money to realise this. As hardworking as she is, she is seeking a loan of $1000 from Kiva to help her realise this dream.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Monica

texts.en:
Monica A. is 46 years. She is married, and has five children. Having never gone to school, she is illiterate. Monica started her business of selling boiled maize in 2004. She boils and sells the maize at a garage near the Kiambiu slums, where she and her family resides. 

Initially, she did casual labour where she would do laundry for people in the surrounding estates near the slums. It is with income from this laundry work that she saved up some capital to start over her business. Monica is now a member of the Vumilia Women Group of Action Now Kenya, and so far, she has received a loan of $57, which she used to revive her maize boiling business through purchase of stock, and has successfully repaid. She has also has received a loan of $ 85 that she used to pay school fees for her children. She is still making repayments for this loan. 

Monica has been experiencing some difficulties in her business, since she only has a small sufuria (cooking pot), which she uses to boil maize. The small sufuria forces her to boil the maize in two or three batches, in order to satisfy her customers. Many times however, she runs out of time while trying to boil the second or third round of maize, when the customers are out on a brief lunch break. She therefore asks them to wait till the next batch is ready.  Because they have a short lunch brunch, many customers are forced to get food from other places, or to go back to work hungry if they can’t afford food that is more costly. This means therefore that often times, Monica only manages to sell the first batch of maize that is ready on time, and is left with the second batch of cooked maize that she is forced to carry back home. This ends up as a loss to her small business.

Given a loan of $75, which she will receive in kind, Monica will purchase a big sufuria (cooking pot) and a jiko (cooking stove). The new additions to her business will enable her to boil more maize on the go, hence manage to sell all the stock for the day. This will also ensure that her customers get enough maize over their brief lunch break, hence they don’t have to spend more money for lunch, or go back to work while still hungry. In return, Monica will now get a higher income that will enable her to support her family, and take her children to school. The repayment period for her loan will be between 8 – 15 months.

loans.use: Purchase of a big sufuria (cooking pot) and a jiko (cooking stove).

loans.name: Christine

texts.en:
Chritine is a 46 year old single mother with two children aged 18 and 22. She also supports five dependents who are all going to school.

She begun a secretarial business one and a half years ago. She started the business with $US 1,450. She raised $US 500 from savings of her previous employment and $US 950 from a loan from SAO MFI.

She has skills in computer designing and business adminstration which she acquired from a business college.

Christine wants to borrow $1000 to buy a Riso graph stationery printing machine which will make her competitive by providing quality services.

Chritine wants to expand her business so that she is able to provide a variety of secretarial services and increase the number of employees from two to four.
 
With this loan, she hopes to expand her business increase profitabilty which will contribute to increase in her income.

loans.use: Purchase of a secretarial printing machine
