payments.comment: Christine's business is doing well, although of recent Kampala has been having many demostrations against government giving a way a natural forest to investors.Every two days there have been demostrations which affect the follow of business.Some times powe is switched off.

loans.name: Esther

texts.en: Madam O., a 47 year-old woman with 6 children, has a livesock farm where she rears local goats and sheep for sale. Her farm is producing well nourished varieties and she wants to expand livestock farm. She is seeking a loan of $1000 from Kiva to enable her expand and produce more. She has been trained using the TEACH lending model of Kraban Support Foundation.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Juliana

texts.en: A. is a 46 year-old woman who sells pots and bowls made of clay, baskets and yams. She goes on a journey to the producing centres to buy the goods and retails them to her customers. She does not have enough funds to buy the goods these days. She needs help and so is seeking a loan of $800 from Kiva. She is hardworking and can pay it back.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Charlotte

texts.en: Selling kenkey, a local food, is a popular activity at a community called Abokobi in Ghana. Charlotte produces and trades in kenkey in her community. She has a good market for her business. She has been a trainee of Kraban Support Foundation's TEACH programme and benefited immensely from the record-keeping training program. She needs a working capital loan of $750 to support her business.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en: Madam Comfort sells kenkey and fish. She sells to students and the general public. She wants to open a "chop bar" where she can sell her food. She is seeking a loan of $750 from Kiva to help her open the bar.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Charles

texts.en:
Charles O. is 49 years old, and is living with HIV within the Kibera slums of Nairobi. He is married and has two wives, one living with him in Kibera, and the other living with his aging mother back in his home village in Busia District, in the Western Province of Kenya. In total Charles has 11 children, two of which with his first wife, now deceased. Three of his children - all daughters - are married, but the other 8 children, together with his wives and his mother all depend on him.

Charles started his hotel in 1999, after he got some savings money from his grocery shop, still in Kibera. He did this in order to diversify his business, and he has continued to run both businesses since. He works together with his wife in this business, and has also employed two employees to assist with the workload. Some of the favorite foods that he serves in his hotel include mandazi (similar to doughnuts), chapatti (a kind of unleavened bread made from wheat flour), beef stew, fish, ugali (A paste made from a mixture of maize meal and water), beans and githeri (made from a mixture of maize and beans boiled together then fried). Charles is a member of the Agape group of Action Now Kenya, within the Kibera slums, and has so far received loans of $57 and $85, which he used to buy stock for his hotel. Charles also received $115 from his group, which he used to buy 2 bags of cement and sand to plaster the walls of the hotel for better presentation. Charles has also been trained by ANK on living with HIV/AIDS, and has learnt about small business management and operation, together with loan management. 

Given the loan of $225, which is repayable within a period of 8 – 14 months, Charles intends to completely refurbish his hotel by fabricating a new set of chairs and tables which will be designed to save space through the sitting arrangement. This will be the first phase where two tables, with six seats each, will be fabricated. Once the loan is repaid, he intends to borrow an additional loan to make another two tables, to ensure that he has a sitting capacity of 24 people at any one time. Currently his hotel can only sit about 10 customers, yet he feels that there is space to accommodate more people. Through this support, Charles will be assured of additional income, due to the extra business created through the sitting arrangement in the hotel. Charles also hopes that in future as the business continues to expand, his hotel will create additional job opportunities for more people within the Kibera slums. He also intends in future on expanding by buying a television set and video machine, through which to attract more customers, and to also provide some educational information for his customers.

loans.use: Purchase of furniture to refurbish the hotel

loans.name: Firudin

texts.en: Firudin M. owns a small gas station in the town of Khachmaz located in the North Eastern part of Azerbaijan. Firudin is looking for funding so that he can invest in a cover for his one pump gas station. He knows that people will pass his gas station when it is raining in order to go to another gas station that has a cover. He feels that a cover will increase his business and therefore his profit.

loans.use: To invest in a cover for his gas station

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary is the mother of 5 children. She sells kenkey and fried fish in addition to soft drinks. She needs a loan of $975 from Kiva because she wants to expand her sales by opening a mini restaurant pouplarly called "chop bar" and also take in more crates of soft drinks. She has been a trustworthy and a capable client and she has the ability of paying back her KIVA loan promptly.

loans.use: Buy soft drinks and open a chop bar

loans.name: Anar

texts.en: Anar H. is a local taxi driver in the town of Khachmaz located in the North Eastern part of Azerbaijan. Anar is looking for funding so that he can purchase new tires for his taxi so that he can keep his cab on the road.

loans.use: To purchase new tires for his Taxi Cab

loans.name: Esther

texts.en: Madam Esther is a 50 year-old woman. She does goat rearing on a large scale. She sells to butchers and individuals. She needs a loan of $975 from Kiva to build a large pen to house her livestock since her goats are producing at a fast rate.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Ama

texts.en: Ama is 52 years old and a mother of 6 children. She is a single parent and caters for the family needs as well as their schooling. To be able to do this, she sells flour and other pastry ingredients at the Central Business District in Takoradi. She has done this business to get her first son through first grade technical school. She took part in the TEACH sessions of Kraban Support Foundation in October, 2006. She wants Kiva to assist her with the loan to increase her capital base.

loans.use: Capital

loans.name: Margret

texts.en: Margie, as she is called, sell yams and smoked fish. She buys the fish in cartons from the harbour and smokes them herself. She also buys yams from farmers in bulk and sells to the public. She needs a loan of $800 from Kiva because she wants to take in more goods for sale.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Ernestina

texts.en: P. lives in Dodowa in the Dangme West district of the Greater Accra Region. She sell babies' wear, towels, pomades, rubber bowls, and so on. She sells in the community's market and carrying goods into and out of the market every day is a problem. She wants to open her own shop where she can sell her goods. She is seeking a loan of $775 from Kiva to enable her do so.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Dorcas

texts.en:
Dorcas is a 30 year-old lady who operates a drinking bar. She sells soft drinks such as Coca-Cola, Pepsi, Fanta, Sprite, Mirinda, and other drinks like beer, Stone Lager, Castle Milk Stout, Guiness and so on.

She is seeking a loan of $1000 from Kiva because she wants to open a spacious bar that can serve 100 clients at a time and also take in more drinks to serve her customers.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Florence

texts.en: Florence is a married woman and a mother of 6. She runs a small machine shop that sharpens cutlasses, hoes, knives and other farming tools. She also retails these items in the outlying farming communities on their respective market days. The major farming season is about to begin in March. She is therefore seeking Kiva's assistance to increase her market share of farming tools. She has been a beneficiary of Kraban's TEACH sessions which will help her manage the loan if it is granted.

loans.use: Capital

loans.name: Charity

texts.en: Salah is a market woman who sells foodstuffs and vegetables. Her goods get damaged when there is a slight change in weather. She wants to build a shop where she can store her goods and sell them. She also wants to order more goods. She needs a loan of $900 from Kiva to enable her to undertake this project.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Teyyub

texts.en:
Teyyub is Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan, Lachin  region, settled in the Absheron region. He is married and has a child.
11 years ago he decided to start this business.
Having borrowed $400, he bought 6 sheep.
The second time he borrowed $800 to build a stable.
Now he requests a loan of $1200 to build a butcher shop.

loans.use: To build a butcher shop

loans.name: Sata

texts.en: Sata is a married woman with 3 children. She is 45 years old. She deals in the sale of cereals. These include maize, beans, millet and groundnuts. A unique feature of her business is that she buys in bulk from Techiman, a major market center in the middle part of the country. She distributes to her clients and sells as well. She wants to access the loan to increase the number of sacks she buys due to the high demand she has had for some time now. She also happens to be a beneficiary of the TEACH sessions provided by Kraban.

loans.use: Capital

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en: Victoria lives in Dodowa in the Dangme West district of the Greater Accra Region of Ghana. She bakes cakes, pies of different kinds, chips, etc., and sells to students especially. She used to buy the flour in bags and bake in large quantity. She can no longer provide for these students because their population has gotten so large. She needs a loan of $850 from Kiva to help her bake to the students' demand.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Juliana

texts.en: Juliana T. lives in a High School community in Dodowa in the Greater Accra Region of Ghana. She sells fried yams and fish to the students. She travels a long distance from her place to a farming community to buy the yams in bulk. Because of the cost of transporting the yams to her place, which she cannot afford, she stopped going for the yams. She is seeking a loan of $900 from Kiva to enable her get back to her business.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Khaleddin

texts.en:
Khaleddin has 20 years of experience in this business. He is a professional architect in brick laying and concrete building. He has received several loans to buy the building materials like timber cement ,sand,aggregate stones, nails for roofing,labor etc.
He is a honest and respectful man.
Now he requests a loan of $1000 to buy a planing machine.
He would like to expand this business but lacks the capital.
Khaleddin was born in 1960 in Yenikand village,Salyan region.He is married and has 3 children.

loans.use: To buy a planing machine

loans.name: Abigail

texts.en: Abigail is a hairdresser. She owns a salon and has five (5) apprentices. She complained bitterly when visited one afternoon of not having enough hair driers and creams even though a lot of women patronize her salon. She is seriously in need and of help to keep her in business. She is seeking a loan of $900 to help her purchase these items.

loans.use: Purchase equipment and supplies

loans.name: Esbend

texts.en:
Esbend is a very kind, friendly and hard-working person. She has had her business for 3 years and it allows her to support her family. 
This 52-year-old woman is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan, Fizuli region settled in  Fizuli region, Ehmedbeyli village.She is married and has a child.
She is optimistic that her business will succeed as she will be able to supply different types of customers daily.
Now she needs a loan of $600 to purchase more foodstuffs to offer her customers and in this way increase her income.

loans.use: To buy foodstuffs

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en: Agnes (the seated lady) sells second-hand footwear in the market. She displays her goods on the ground in the market for sale. She used to receive the goods in several bales but due to the insecure nature of her items, she is not able to receive more goods even though demand from her is very high. She is in need of the loan because she wants to build a shop where she can keep and sell the footwear. She is seeking a loan of $950 from Kiva to enable her build the shop.

loans.use: Build a shoe shop

loans.name: Yadulla

texts.en:
48-year-old Yadulla lives in Khaladj village,  Salyan region. He has 2 children.
4 years ago he decided to start this business.
Yadulla’s plan is to raise his income level to be able to provide for his children’s education in high school. He intends to do this by increasing the number of his cattle.
Now he requests a loan of $1000 to open a butcher shop. 
Every day he goes to the market and stores to offer his products.
His neighbors know him and buy meat from him because his meat is always fresh.

loans.use: To open a butcher shop

loans.name: Balabey

texts.en:
Balabey has plot of land. 
6 years ago he decided to start this business. The soil of his plot of land is salty. He requests a loan of $800 to irrigate his plot of land. 
Balabey was born in 1956 in Khaladj village,Salyan region. He is married and has 2 children.

loans.use: To buy irrigation material

loans.name: Shukufat

texts.en: Shukufat is Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-ocupied territory of Azerbaijan Gubadli region, settled in Sumgait city. This 23-year-old man has been engaged in his business for 2 years. Shukufat sells jean clothes. He supports his family with this business. Now he needs a loan amounting $1200 to be busy with selling industrial goods.

loans.use: To be busy with selling industrial goods

loans.name: Sevil

texts.en:
You can see in the picture a very kind, friendly, hard-working woman. She has had this business for 20 years.
Sevil was born in 1950 in the city of Baku. She is a widow and has 3 children.
She is a high school mathematics teacher. 
Now she needs a loan of $1200 to buy a new computer to make her work easier. She tutors students for examinations. The computer would provide her with internet access to advance her students' educational level.

loans.use: To buy a new computer to ease her work and to administer tests for students

loans.name: Ayaz

texts.en:
Ayaz was born in Gubadli region of Azerbaijan. He is Internally Displaced Person (IDP). He settled with his family and 3 children in Sumgait. He is 45. Difficulties of life forced them to start the business. He is the only breadwinner in the family. In the beginning he used to sell vegetables. By borrowing the loan amount of $300 he has increased the range of foods: has bought 12 bags onions, 8 bags potatoes.

Ayaz applies for $1200 loan. He plans to be busy with the sale agricultural products.

loans.use: He plans to be busy with sale agricultural products

loans.name: Fazil

texts.en:
Fazil was born in Gubadli region of Azerbaijan. He is Internally Displaced Person (IDP). He settled with his family and 3 children in Sumgait. He is 48. Difficulties of life forced them to start the business. He is the only breadwinner in the family. In the beginning he used to sell vegetables. By borrowing the loan amount of $800 he has bought 12 bags onions, 8 bags potatoes and he rented food store.

Fazil applies for $1200. He plans to open his own food market.

loans.use: He plans to open his own food market

loans.name: Serhed

texts.en:
Serhed has 2 years of experience in this business.
He applies for a loan of $800 to buy a lathe.
He is Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan Fizuli region, settled in Fizuli region, Gayidish vilage. He is married and has 2 children.

loans.use: To buy a lathe

loans.name: Elshan

texts.en: Elshan is Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-ocupied territory of Azerbaijan Gubadli region, settled in Sumgait city. He is 30 and has 1 child. By borrowing the loan amount of $600 he has bought onions, potatoes and he rented food store at the market. Elshan applies for $1200 to open his own shop and to increase food assortment.

loans.use: He plans to open his own food market

loans.name: Asiman

texts.en:
Asiman has 10 years of experience in this business.
Having borrowed $200 he bought 4 pregnant sheep.
The second time he borrowed  $300 and bought 6 pregnant sheep.
The third time he borrowed a loan of $500 to buy 2 cows.
Now he requests a loan of $1000 to buy 4 male calves.Asiman was born in 1961 in Yenikand village, Salyan region. He is married and has a child.

loans.use: To buy 4 male calves

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Grace is a trader. She is 35 years old. She sells both ladies' and gents' jeans wear. She wants to change her life by expanding her business. She is seeking a loan of $900 from Kiva to enable her open a shop of her own.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Agil

texts.en: Agil is Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-ocupied territory of Azerbaijan Lachin region, settled in Sumgait city. This 27-year-old man has been engaged in his business for 7 years. Agil sells jean clothes. He supports his family with this business. Agil needs a loan amounting $1200 to be busy with selling the goods.

loans.use: To be busy with selling the industrial goods

loans.name: Sudmila

texts.en:
Sudmila has a small store where she sells foodstuffs. She started this business 4 years ago.
This business has allowed her family to have a better income.
Having borrowed $400 she bought foodstuffs.
Now she needs a loan of $600 to expand the area of her store.
Sudmila is 40 years old. She is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan, Fizuli  region, settled in the Finnish houses, which are built temporarily on the front line in the Fizuli region. Sudmila is single.

loans.use: To expand the area of her store

loans.name: Yalchin

texts.en:
Yalchin is 29 years old and has had a farming business since 2001. He grows fruit. 
Now he needs a loan of $1000 to buy fertilizer.
Yalchin lives in Khaladj village, Salyan region.  Yalchin is a single man.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en: Rebecca operates a drinking spot in her community. She sells a variety of drinks ranging from local to foreign. Becky has participated in the TEACH Lending skills training of Kraban Support  Foundation and therefore requires a loan amount of $800 from Kiva to enable her to expand and improve upon her business by purchasing more drinks to sell to her customers. She wants her drinking pub  to be the number one spot in her community.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Salome

texts.en:
Auntie Salome lives in Pantang, a suburb of Accra in the Greater Accra Region of Ghana. She lives in a community with a junior high school and she supplies the students with food. She sells various kinds of local meals.

Due to the increase in the intake of students, her demand is very high. She is seeking a loan of $700 from Kiva to enable her to cook enough food for the students.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary lives in Pantang, a suburb of Accra in the Greater Accra Region of Ghana. She sells various items at a table-top store. Some of the items she sells include milk, nido, milo, sugar, tinned fish, batteries, and so on. Her dream is to open her own shop. With this in mind she is seeking a loan of $750 from Kiva to enable her open her own shop.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Matilda

texts.en: Matilda is a 32 year-old woman who lives in Pantang, Accra, Ghana. She sells both ladies' and gents' footwear. She carries her goods in basket and sells from house to house to her clients. She wishes she could open her own shop where she can sell her goods. She is seeking a loan of $750 to enable her open a shop.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Kate

texts.en:
Kate sells variety of foods in her community, Pantang, Ghana, where she lives. She sells local meals such as rice-and-stew, beans-and-gari, a product from cassava, yam-and-stew, etc.

She sells in a very poor structure, and due to this her clients feel insecure when eating. She wants to build a safe structure where she can sell and serve her customers. She needs a loan of $750 from Kiva to enable her put up this structure.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Auntie Grace sells vegetables and other ingredients used in food preparation. She sells tomatoes, pepper, garden eggs, salt, onions and cooking oil from palm fruit. She is unable to provide as much as her community demands because she has no money to buy the items from wholesalers. She is seeking a loan of $750 from Kiva to enable her buy enough items for sale.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Diana

texts.en:
Maame O. sells fante kenkey to restaurants and individuals to retail. This is a local food prepared from maize. She cooks the kenkey per the demands of these restaurants and individuals.

At certain times she is unable to provide the quantity demanded. When asked, on a visit to her kitchen, why she could not provide, she said, "The price of a bag of maize is very expensive and I cannot afford to buy it, making me not cook when the quantity demanded is high." She is seeking a loan of $700 from Kiva.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Róger

texts.en:
Mister A. holds a position as a director for a school center and is also owner of a small store in the local market, which he wants to expand with the help of a PRISMA loan. With the loan he would like to increase his earnings by 30%, which will allow him to better the economic and social situation of his family, principally that of his children.

Translated from Spanish by Kiva Volunteer, Kristin Connor

El señor A. desempeña sus funciones como director de un centro escolar, a su vez es dueño de una pequeña tienda en un mercado local, la cual quiere hecer crecer a través del préstamo que PRISMA le brinde. Con el préstamo piensa incrementar sus ingresos en un 30%, lo cual le permitirá mejorar las condiciones económicas y sociales de su familia y principalmente de sus hijos.

loans.use: The money will be used to stock the owner's store with new products(such as clothes, cosmetics, shoes, etc.)

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Susana

texts.en:
Ms. Susana D. Gonzales is a very enterprising person who has owned a novelty/gift shop for one year. Her business has been successful. To prepare for the upcoming Easter season, she needs to buy new merchandise. Therefore, she is seeking a loan in the amount of $1,200 with a 12-month repayment term.

Espanol: La Sra. D. Gonzales es una persona muy emprendedora, tiene mas de 12 meses con un negocio de novedades y regalos. El negocio a marchado bien, se esta preparando para la proxima temporada de Pascua y necesita comprar mercancia, por lo cual solicita un prestamo de $1,200 Dllr. El cual piensa pagar en un plazo de 12 meses.

loans.use: To buy merchandise

loans.name: Salome

texts.en:
Mr. M. is a successful business owner who has been producing and selling "chicharron" (a snack of fried pork skins) for over two years. He is in need of transportation equipment, and is seeking a $1,200 loan, with a 12 month repayment term.

Espanol: El Sr. M. es una persona muy exitosa cuenta con mas de 2 anos en el Negocio de elaboracion y venta de chicharron, por lo cual solicita un prestamo de $1200.00 Dllrs para la compra de equipo de transporte, los cuales piensa pagar en 12 meses.

loans.use: To buy a truck to transport merchandise

loans.name: Manuel

texts.en:
Mr. R. has his own barber shop, which he has owned for over 50 years. He is a senior citizen and the business is located inside his home. He is seeking a loan in the amount of $1,100 to remodel his shop, which he plans to repay in 12 months.

Espanol: El Sr. R. tiene una peluqueria, de la cual es dueno por mas de 50 anos. El es una persona de edad y el negocio esta en su casa. El solicita un prestamo de $1,100 Dllrs. para remodelar su local. El piensa pagarlo en 12 meses.

loans.use: Remodel his barber shop which is inside his home

loans.name: Jose Luis

texts.en:
Mr. S. has a bakery and the business is running great, but he would like to buy more equipment to increase the production of bread which is why he is asking for a $1200 loan, to be repaid in 12 months.

Espanol: El Sr. S. tiene una panaderia y el negocio ha funcionado muy bien. Pero a el le gustaria comprar mas equipo para aumentar la producion de pan, por lo cual solicita un prestamo por $1,200 Dllrs, los cuales piensa pagar en un plazo de 12 meses.

loans.use: To buy bakery equipment

loans.name: Francisco Javier

texts.en:
Mr T. is  a mechanic. He  mostly  repairs heavy
industrial machinery. He  is  asking  for a loan of
$1000.00 to  buy  more tools and equipment for his 
shop, he  will repay  the  loan  within the  next
year.

loans.use: To buy equipment and hardware.

loans.name: Syed Ibrahem Shah

texts.en:
S. Ibrahem S. has been working for 5 years in this business. He sells all types of groceries such as sugar, tea, rice, milk, ghee, flour, jam, etc.

S. Ibrahem S. was born in 1973, and lives in a household of 5  in district 5 of Kabul, Afghanistan. He is 34 years old and married, his wife works in her own tailoring shop. They are a very close couple who have worked hard ever since they married. With their income they have been able to own their house and make improvements to it.

They hope to get ahead with their businesses and to keep working.

loans.use: To buy flour, rice, ghee, sugar, etc.

loans.name: Fatima

texts.en:
Fatima is a 31-year old mother of 3 children living in district 13 of Kabul, Afghanistan. She has been working for 10 years in carpet weaving.

She is married and her husband works in his own mechanic's shop. She started her business during the war to support her family financially. Then she taught her daughter the work. Together with her she can complete one carpet in 6 months.

She hopes to get ahead with their businesses and to keep working.

loans.use: To buy materials

loans.name: Kokai

texts.en:
Kokai has a shared business with her husband. They have 4 years of experience in general stores. They sell all types of groceries. Before she had her business, Kokai worked cleaning houses and cooking. 

Kokai is 38 years old and lives in a household of 6 in district 2 of Kabul, Afghanistan. Their general store is in the bazaar.

They aspire to have their business become well established. With the income they generate from it, they hope to improve their home, which is currently constructed of cane. 

She took a loan to expand the inventory to include rice, cooking oil, sugar, as well as dairy products. She hopes to make physical improvements to the shop with the income they will generate.

loans.use: Buying rice, tea, sugar, jam, flour, etc.

loans.name: Azmari

texts.en:
Azmari sells and and buys used metal. He has 3 years' experience in the current business, before that he had a electronic shop but due to a lack of income he left that shop.

Azmari is 40 years old and was born in Kabul where he still lives, in a household of 8, in district 5. He started his current business with less materials, then he took a loan from AFSG to buy  used metals to support the family better financially.

Azmari's sons are working in an electronic shop so they have been able to own their house and make improvements to it. He hopes they all get ahead with their businesses and keep working.

loans.use: To buy materials

loans.name: Sarkhan

texts.en:
Sarkhan is Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-ocupied territory of Azerbaijan Zangilan. He and his family settled in Sumgait city. Sarkhan was born in 1963. He is married and has 3 children. He sells fruits and vegetables in his own car. He does not have a shop. His car is his own but it does not work well. This problem motivated him to expand his business. Having borrowed a loan amount of $800, he repaired his car and bought the fruits and vegetables.
Now Sarkhan needs a loan amounting $1100 to build a shop. He plans to open his own mini market.

loans.use: He plans to open his own mini market

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Emily would like to buy steers

loans.name: Liuamaama

texts.en:
Liuamaama A. is a hard-working woman of sixty- eight years of age. Her proposed loan will be used to buy materials to develop the land for growing her farm. She has fourteen children; five have already passed away, and nine are still living. Three of Liuamaama’s children are married, and six children are still in school. Her husband works to maintain their farm in good condition. The family also supports some of their relatives who live with them and help on the farm.

Liuamaama owns a permanent stall in the Public Market where she can sell the products from her farm. She strongly believes in her business and its development.

loans.use: To use as working capital for buying and selling fruits and vegetables in the market

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Gladys would like to buy 8 steers

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Joyce would like to buy a dairy cow

loans.name: Fonofili

texts.en:
Fonofili L. is forty years old and has five children. She runs a canteen of Samoan food and sells it at the market. Fonofili feels good about the money she earns and believes she can earn more. She earns a hundred tala (USD 36.30) or more per day from her selling.

The loan will be used to buy more foodstuffs and other cooking equipment because of the increase in her customers' demand. This is a dream of Fonofili's, and she does not want to fail. Her husband and his brother are also encouraging Fonofili with ways to improve her business. They are giving her support by processing the umu to bake the goods like taro, breadfruit, and banana for their canteen business. Fonofili also mentioned that she has no doubt in selling her products.

loans.use: To purchase additional foodstuff for her food stall and cooking implements and utensils

loans.name: Penina

texts.en: Penina S. is a young talented woman of thirty-two who believes in herself.  She is a mother of five children, and they spend most of their time with her husband developing their business. She strongly believes in her small farm because her husband and her two brothers are giving her support.  She sells her products at the market, and she has no doubt that she will succeed because of the growth of the customers each and every day of the week.  Penina suggested that her business would never fail because her family works full time to maintain their farm in good condition.

loans.use: To purchase organic fertilizers, pesticides, fungicides and farm implements

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Rhoda would like to buy household goods for her shop

loans.name: Leatulai

texts.en:
Leatulai M. is forty-five years old with four children. She and her husband both struggled for a better life for their children. One of their children is working while the other three are still in school.

Leatulai owns a piggery business in which she sells live pigs. Her piggery is divided into three different groups: the big ones, medium and the small ones. There are more than fifty pigs all together in Leatuali's piggery including the ten little pigs. Her husband and the kids help feed the animals in the morning and in the evening. She has no problem with her business. Nearly ten customers per week buy pigs for family faalavelave (village functions such as weddings, funerals, birthdays and special occasions). This is proof to her that her business project is growing.

loans.use: To purchase cement, fencing and roofing materials to improve and expand her pigpen

loans.name: Faalevela

texts.en:
Faalevela R. was born and raised in Avao Savaii. She’s now fifty-four years of age and has six children. Faalevela believes that her small business project really helps her support her family. She also believes that she is capable of running the business because she has support from family and friends, which makes things easier for her.

She started off with only a small retail shop, and now her business is being enlarged. Her customers have increased, and their needs have grown. Even though there are heaps of shops within her village, Faalevela provides the services that people need. That’s why her business is successful. Faalevela also provides the best quality goods with a fair price to satisfy the needs of her customers. She will use her loan to buy products for her shop and to renovate her business shop if it is damaged.

loans.use: To purchase additional products for her retail shop

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Catherine would like to buy three steers

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Mateyian Anderson would like to buy 8 steers

loans.name: Vaitolo

texts.en:
Vaitolo V. was born in 1966 at Motootua. She has six children. Vaitolo is a strong and hard-working woman. Vaitolo has two small business projects: one is a plantation, and the other is a vegetable garden. She has a strong heart. If she can do two business projects, she also can do more.

Mrs. V. hired two village boys to help her plant, weed, and clean her plantation each day. She has a strong heart and believes that her business is growing, as she receives more than two hundred tala a day (USD 72.60). Vaitolo covers half of a quarter-acre with her plantation. She also owns a permanent block at the Public Market in town, where she serves more than thirty customers a day.

loans.use: To purchase seeds, planting materials, fertilizers, and pesticides

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Joyce would like to buy 8 steers

loans.name: Lipine

texts.en: Lipine M. is a well-known businesswoman.  She works hard in order to satisfy the needs of her family. She has nine children; five are married, and three are not married.  Lipine comes from a family of six people.  She is a hard-working person and strives to earn income one day at a time.  She earns 150 tala (USD 50) a day for selling her products at the market, to small retailers, and at her residence.

loans.use: To purchase seeds, planting materials, fertilizers, and pesticides

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Mukana would like to buy beadwork materials

loans.name: Simeamativa

texts.en: Simeamativa F. is from the village of Fasitoo-uta.  She has two children: one is in school, and the eldest is married. She has seven members in her family including her and her kids. Simeamativa does elei-printing every night so that she has no shortage of material to sell to her customers on the following day.  Mrs. F. is a strong worker and works hard to meet her goals.  Having her loan will help her buy more equipment to run her business.  She sells an average of twenty elei-printing materials a day. For this, she receives more than 150 tala (US$50) a day.  She said her business really helps her finance the needs of her family.

loans.use: To purchase additional printing materials like stencils, ink, fabrics, wooden blocks

loans.name: Tess

texts.en: Tess E. is from Nofoalii, and her business is elei printing -- a traditional Samoan way of printing fabrics.  She runs the business on her own.  She has two children, and she’s from a family of seven.  Tess has used every loan she has received to buy equipment and materials to improve her business.  She said that if you provide good materials or good quality products, you receive more money.  She receives more than 90 tala (USD 27) a day from selling her elei.  She has noticed that her business is improving, as more people come to her to for her elei materials.

loans.use: To purchase additional printing materials like stencils, ink, fabrics, wooden blocks

loans.name: Luisa

texts.en: Luisa L. is from the village of Fasitoo-uta.  Her business project is sewing.  She is very happy with her talent because it helps her to support her family.  She is a woman of many talents, but she likes sewing the best.  L. said she could sew more than twenty articles of clothing a day, along with additional materials.  She believes having this project is very unique.   She has no doubt about succeeding.  L. will be using her loan to help her buy tools to fix her machine if it is damaged, as well as needles and other supplies to run her business.

loans.use: To purchase tools for maintaining her machine and additional stock of fabrics

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Margaret would like to buy cereals for her retail shop

loans.name: Filiga

texts.en: Filiga has six children: two passed away, and four stay at home.   Filiga runs a canteen and sells ice-cakes and other snack items.  She sells some of her products at her village school and some at her home.  Her canteen really helps her contribute to the needs of her family.  She struggles most of the time, but she has succeeded.  She receives more than a hundred tala (US$30) a day for running this business.  She is confident about doing everything that will improve her business.  She will use her loan to buy things that she needs (e.g. more products to sell and equipment she needs for her business).  She is delighted about the project she is doing because it gives her money to feed her family.  She has a strong heart and believes that she will become a better businesswoman in the future.

loans.use: To purchase foodstuffs and additional cooking equipment -- stove, pots and pans for her canteen

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Elizabeth would like to purchase a dairy cow

loans.name: Enite

texts.en: L. is from the village of Utualii.  She runs a small retail shop.  She is improving her business, and she has no doubt about running her business.   L. said that all she is doing is focusing on her business. L. is working hard to have every different type of merchandise available to sell in her shop to satisfy her customers, so that she can earn profits to improve her business.  L. will use her loan to buy goods to sell at her shop and also to buy paint, woods, and corrugated roofing iron to renovate her shop if it is damaged.

loans.use: To purchase additional stocks for her retail shop and building materials to improve her shop

loans.name: Levale

texts.en: Levale T. is a hard-working woman who believes in herself.  She is fifty-seven years of age, and she has six children.  Levale specializes in making pork buns because of the experience she has. She has the most popular pork buns within her village.  She sells her products at her village school and at her home everyday of the week except for Saturday.  She has good support from her two daughters who help her out with processing.  Levale is looking for a permanent stall at the flea market where she can develop her business because it is a really good place for selling.  She earns 100 tala (USD 30) a day or more from the sale of her goods.  She uses her loan to buy flour and other stuff she needs to make her pork buns.

loans.use: To purchase additional ingredients, steamers, and other cooking utensils

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Ann would like to buy more clothes for her boutique shop

loans.name: Evelina

texts.en: Evelina S.'s talent is sewing.  This is what she wants to do for most of her life.  She’s happy about her talent because it really helps her contribute to the needs of her family.  She said that she could sew more than twenty-five articles of clothing a day.  She believes having this project is very important to her and her family.    Evelina intends to use her loan to buy equipment to fix her sewing machine and materials to sew for her customers.

loans.use: To purchase tools for maintaining her machine and additional stock of fabrics

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Jane would like to buy a dairy cow

loans.name: Ofe

texts.en: Ofe T. is from the village of Nofoalii.  She  runs a small retail shop. Ofe said all she’s doing is focusing on her business.  Her children help her to look after the shop if she is not available.  Ofe's shop has so many goods to choose from.  She is also confident about running her business by herself.  Ofe intends to use her loan to purchase additional goods to sell at her shop, and to buy paint, wood and corrugated roofing iron to renovate her shop.

loans.use: To purchase additional stocks for her retail shop and building materials to improve her shop

loans.name: Faleseu

texts.en: Faleseu R. is from the village of Nofoalii.  Her business project is sewing her family clothes and clothes for other people.  She is very happy about the talent that she has because it helps her to contribute to the needs of her family.  She is a woman of many talents, but her best talent is sewing.  She intends to use her loan to buy tools to fix her machine, as well as needles and everything that she needs to improve her business.  She believes that she will become a good businesswoman in the future.

loans.use: To purchase tools for maintaining her machine and additional stock of fabrics

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Jane would like to buy a dairy cow

loans.name: Kereta

texts.en: Kereta L. has a small fruit and vegetable farm for her business. Kereta is a hard-working person from the village of Nofoalii.  Kereta's project is well-developed in different ways because of the support of her family and friends. She has done a great job by selling her goods at the market.  She earns a hundred tala (USD 30) a day from her selling.  Kereta is a woman with the guts to get the job done. She goes to her plantation everyday to check on it, as well as to weed and to plant more taro, banana and other fruits and vegetables.  Kereta and her family survive on the profits from this farm.

loans.use: To purchase seeds, planting materials, fertilizers, and pesticides

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Sarah would like to buy a dairy cow

loans.name: Faavae

texts.en: Faavae is a hard-working woman who believes in herself.  Her special skill is making pork buns.  She is the most wanted maker of pork buns within her village.  She sells her product at her village school, in town, and at her residence.  She has good support from her family and mates.  She earns more than hundred tala (USD 30) a day from selling her pork cake.  She has seen her business improve with an increase in customers coming and buying from her.

loans.use: To purchase additional ingredients, steamers, and other cooking utensils

loans.name: Hinemoa

texts.en: Hinemoa L. loves sewing.  She started sewing when she was twelve years old.  Hinemoa sews clothes for her family and for people who come to her.  Hinemoa is a fine young woman. She sews more than thirty articles of clothing a day.  She can sew baby’s clothes, shirts, ielavalava, etc.  She earns more than 150 tala (USD 50) a day.  She is very happy about this business because its helps her contribute to the needs of her family.

loans.use: To purchase tools for maintaining her machine and additional stock of fabrics

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Lydia would like to buy a dairy cow

loans.name: Lomialagi

texts.en: Lomialagi S. is a promising businessperson.  She loves buying the best quality products to sell to her customers.   Lomialagi has no doubt about running her business, because she has the support of her family.  She started off with only a small retail shop, and now her business is being enlarged.  This is because the number of her customers and their needs have grown.   Lomialagi provides good service to her customers.  She also has the knowledge to help her customers with what they need.  She will use her loan to buy more wholesale goods to fill up her empty shelves, and to buy paint and wood to fix damages in her shop in order to encourage customers to come buy from her.  She believes that having this business is a very good chance for her to help her family.

loans.use: To purchase additional goods for her retail shop

loans.name: Matala

texts.en: Matala F. has a stall in the flea market where she sells different kinds of things: clothes, handicrafts, earrings, necklaces, and other products.  F. is a hard-working woman from the village of Moataa.  She goes to her flea market stall and stays there for the whole day to sell her products.  She has two daughters to help look after the business if she’s not available.  Matala earns more than ninety tala (USD 30) a day from selling her products. She is very happy because she has a business to help meet the needs of her family.  Matala will use her loan to buy what she needs to run her business.  She provides her best customer service in order to maintain her customers.

loans.use: To purchase additional stocks for her flea market stall

loans.name: Leiaia

texts.en: Leiaia T.'s small business project is the beach fale -- a Samoan-style beach cottage for rent to tourists and vacationers.  Leiaia is from the village of Moataa. She is confident in her customer service.  Leiaia has more than ten beach houses at Moataa.  She earns more than two hundred tala (USD 60) a day during the peak season.  Many tourists come to hire Leiaia's Beach Fale to spend a week there, in addition to staying for school picnics and other events.  Leiaia said she is very delighted about the project that she is doing. She earns money to help put her children to school and help meet the needs of her family.   Leiaia's business has become successful in many ways.

loans.use: To purchase building materials to improve her beach fales

loans.name: Afiwa

texts.en: Afiwa lives in Abokobi, Accra, Ghana. She operates a business that sells soft drinks and beverages with alcohol. She is a client of Kraban Support Foundation (KSF) and has benefited from the organization's training programs and funding opportunities for several years. A loan of $750 from Kiva will enable her to increase her inventory and sales.

loans.use: Buy more beverages to sell

loans.name: Totoa

texts.en:
Totoa L. is from the village of Moataa. She has two business projects: one is Ice-Cake and the other is Pop Corn. Totoa believes that she can do more, but these are things she knows that kids want the most. Totoa is confident about doing two things at one time. She budgets her time in order to have things ready on time. Totoa's relatives give her a hand in preparing her products, but she does most of the things. She delivers her goods to her village school to sell because she says that this is the best place to sell.

Totoa earns a hundred tala (US $30) a day from selling her products. She is very happy because she wouldn’t earn this money without this project. Totoa intends to use her loan to improve her business by buying plastic cups, kool aid, sugar, popcorn nuts, oil and other products to run her business. She is delighted to have these skills, because this business makes things easier for her and her family.

loans.use: To purchase additional ingredients and serving materials for her ice cake business

loans.name: Tolotea

texts.en: Tolotea is from the village of Moataa.  She is very happy about the business that she created.  She is a woman of many talents, but she only chooses one skill to earn money to meet the needs of her family: sewing.  Tolotea's talent came from her mother, which is why she thankful because she continues the legacy of her mother.  She is very happy because she saves money by sewing her clothes.  Tolotea earns more than ninety tala (US$30) a day from customers purchasing the materials that she sews.  She is confident that she can sew more than twenty articles of clothing a day.  She can sew different kinds of clothes as well. Tolotea's loan will be used to purchase tools for maintaining her machine as well as additional fabrics.

loans.use: To purchase tools for maintaining her machine and additional stock of fabrics

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Nancy would like to buy farm fertilizers

loans.name: Aolagi

texts.en: Aolagi I. is forty-eight years of age and has a unique idea for earning money. Her small business project is selling tyres to those who do not have enough cash to buy brand new tyres.  She sells the best quality tyres in different sizes.  Most of her tyres are from New Zealand, and they are a second-hand product.  She intends to use her loan to order more tyres, which will help her earn more money to keep her business running. Her family members are helping her run the business.  She is thankful for her project because it gives her good money to buy food to feed her family.

loans.use: To purchase additional stocks for her tyre selling business

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Maria Jacinta

texts.en:
Maria Jacinta T. S. is from the village of Nofoalii. She has four children: two are in school, and two are at home. Jacinta's husband is also working, and he is very happy about the small business that his wife is running. Jacinta and her husband are both delighted about this project because it gives them extra cash -- it really helps them meet the needs of their family.

The project that Jacinta is working on is ice-cake. Jacinta's small business is favored by the kids, and she said that she does more than three par-rows of ice-cake a day. That means that she is selling more than thirty ice-cakes a day at her village school and to the people of her village. Jacinta plans to use the loan to purchase additional ingredients and serving materials for her business.

loans.use: To purchase additional ingredients and serving materials for her ice cake business

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en: Antie Victoria (lady sitting) sells "wakye", a meal enjoyed by locals and prepared from a special rice and beans grown in her area. She is a client of Kraban Support Foundation (KSF) and has completed several training programs that teach good business practices. She is a good manager of loans and knows how to use them to help her business. She is requesting a loan of $750.00 so she can buy ingredients in bulk and increase her profits.

loans.use: Buy ingredients in bulk

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Pamela would like to pay school fees

loans.name: Akua

texts.en: Akua joined the family of Kaban Support Foundation (KSF) 3 years ago and has benefited from many of its programs, including learning how best to operate her business. She sells "wakye", a special rice and beans dish that is a favorite meal for locals. A loan of $750.00 will enable her to make and sell more food and grow her business.

loans.use: Buy more ingredients

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Elizabeth would like to pay school fees for her children

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Leonida would like to buy more household goods for her retail shop

loans.name: Patience

texts.en: Patience O. is a 36-year-old woman with 3 children. She is a pioneering client of Kraban Support Foundation (KSF) and has gone through several loan management programs with them. She sells porridge and "koose" (made from beans) in a central community location,  and her many customers start their day buying breakfast from her. They buy from her because they know the food is very tasty and is prepared with careful attention to hygiene. She requests a loan of $800.00 so she can buy more bags of beans and maize and serve more customers.

loans.use: Buy bags of beans and maize

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Doreen would like to buy more GNLD products

loans.name: Margerete

texts.en: Antie Margie lives in Abokobi, Accra, Ghana, a community where charcoal is used in every home for cooking. She is the only retail supplier of the fuel in her area. She buys the charcoal from the producing center and sells it at a profit to her customers. Because the cost of each bag has gone up, she is unable to buy enough bags to supply all of her customers. She is seeking a loan of $900.00 to enable her meet the demand and grow her business.

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Woke Pulei would like to buy beadwork materials

loans.name: Rosemary

texts.en: Rosemary sells spare parts for different makes of vehicles. She lives in a community where many vehicle repair shops are located. She is losing business, because she can't afford to buy enough stock. Rosemary is requesting a loan of $1000.00 so she can buy more parts to sell to her customers.

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Margerete

texts.en: Mama K. lives in Abokobi, Accra, Ghana and sells cassava and plantain. She buys from a farming community and transports to her community for sale. She lacks supporting capital to boost her sales. She is seeking a loan of $750.00 from Kiva to enable her to buy more foodstuffs.

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Donata

texts.en: Donata lives in a working community in Abokobi, Accra, Ghana and operates a fast-food stand. Her customers are workers who buy lunch and supper from her stand. Her menu includes fried rice and chicken, plain rice and stew, "wakye", and soft drinks. Her stand is not spacious enough to quickly take care of the number of clients who buy her food. She requests a loan of $900.00 to her expand her stand so she can service more customers in less time.

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Salome

texts.en: Salome is the owner of Jesus Above All Enterprise located at Abokobi in Accra, Ghana. She sells soft drinks, alcoholic beverages and other drinks. Her customer demands are greater than the supply she can afford to buy from the wholesale supplier. She requests a loan of $900.00 to purchase goods for her shop so she can grow her business.

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Ngat

texts.en:
Ngat is a lady of 47. She is single and supports her elderly mother (80). Her brother Thuong, 47, became blind 13 years ago and thus lives also in the same house with his child whom his wife abandoned when she was only 3 months old. The latter is 13 now and is the pride of the family who support her education: she is now in grade 5.

They do not have any land, so they live from making and selling baskets on the neighboring markets. Ngát's brother is also trying his best by working as a laborer a few days a month.

They have borrowed 60$ already twice and need a third loan of 50$. This is to buy bamboo in larger quantities and pay cash, which improves their small business. Their income has increased from less than 8$ per person per month, to over 10$ already. The loan is repaid monthly by 10$ installments.

loans.use: Buy bamboo for making baskets

loans.name: Augustina

texts.en: Madam Augustina operates a drinking spot that she hopes to upgrade to a modern pub in the future. She sells many foreign and local drinks. Her supply comes from producers and distributors at wholesale cost. Because she can not afford to buy enough drinks to grow her business, her business has suffered. She is seeking a loan of $900.00 to buy more supplies for her drinking spot and grow her business.

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Jenifer

texts.en: Jenifer owns a shop and sells soaps, drinks, stationery, candles, soft drinks and other goods. She has a serious shortage of stock, and is seeking a loan of $800.00 so she can replenish the supply of goods in her shop and offer more to her customers.

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Margerete

texts.en: Margie sells soaps, cooking oil, sugar, rice in tins and other merchandise. She lives in a community called Abokobi in Accra, Ghana, and is a client of Kraban Support Foundation (KSF). She has benefited from various programs KSF has offered, including programs on good business practices. A loan of $750.00 will enable her to have more goods to sell to her customers and grow her business.

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en: Maa Comfort lives in Abokobi, Accra, Ghana in a very remote community. She is 42 years old with 5 children. She sells "kenkey" (a local meal from maize) and fried fish to people in her community.  The demand for her food is very high, but she does not have the capital she needs to produce the food in a quantity that will grow her business. She is seeking a loan of $700.00 to enable her serve more food to meet her customer demand

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Esther

texts.en: F. lives in Abokobi, Accra, Ghana. She sells canned fish, tomato paste, dry fish, cooking oils, brooms, and other variety store goods. In order to increase her profits, she needs to have more goods to sell She requests a loan of $750.00 to enable her to buy the stock she needs to increase her business.

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Anita

texts.en: Anita lives in Abokobi, Accra, Ghana and has a shop in which she sells candies, toiletries, body and hair creams, and clothes for men, women and children. She wishes to expand her shop into a mini-supermarket so she can offer more to her customers. She is seeking a loan of $900.00 to enable her realize this dream.

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Assibi

texts.en: Assibi lives in Abokobi, Accra, Ghana. She sells "wakye" a local meal from a special rice and beans. She needs a stable spot where she can sell her food. She is seeking for a loan of $750.00 to enable her open a mini-bar where she can cook more food and sell to more customers.

loans.use: Open a mini-bar where she can sell her food

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en: Lucy is a 30 year-old woman who lives at Abokobi, Accra, Ghana. Her dream is to own one of the biggest supermarkets in her community. Kraban Support Foundation's (KSF's) TEACH program has helped her open a retail shop. Now she wishes to take another step toward her supermarket focus, and she is seeking a loan of $1000.00 to grow her business.

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Olivia

texts.en: Olivia is a 28-year-old lady who lives in Abokobi, Accra, Ghana. She is a client of Kraban Support Foundation (KSF) and has benefited from the organization's programs for 2 years. She sells hair products and body lotions and wishes to expand her operations. She is seeking for a loan of $900.00 to enable her to expand her business.

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en: Madam Lucy (middle) is a seamstress and owns a shop in Abokobi, Accra, Ghana. She sews ladies dresses and sells to shops and individuals. She is seeking a loan of $900.00 to enable her buy the fabrics and materials she needs to increase her business.

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Martha

texts.en: Antie Martha owns a warehouse where she sells farm produce such as maize, beans, groundnuts and local rice in sacks. She buys her wares from producing farms. Because the farm prices of produce has increased, she needs to be able to buy in bulk to keep her business profitable. She is seeking a loan of $1000.00 so she can buy the quantity of produce she needs at a reasonable price.

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Vida

texts.en: Madam Vida lives in Abokobi, Accra, Ghana and owns a shop in which she sells candies, beverages, biscuits, toiletries, tins of rice and other goods. She wishes to expand her operation and is seeking a loan of $900.00 so she can grow her business.

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Betty

texts.en: Antie Betty (lady in cap) sells cooking oils, fresh okra and local green peppers in the community's market. She requests a loan of $500.00 so she can open her own shed in the market where she can sell her goods in the same spot and have more returning customers. she has been a good standing client of Kraban Support Foundation for the past 5 years.

loans.use: Open a stall in the market

loans.name: Denia Iydesa

texts.en:
Hello, my name is Denia Iyodesa and I work primarily selling food items in my grocery store. It is located in my own home and thanks to my business I am able to contribute to the payment of family expenses and to care for my family. Now I am in need of stocking my business because it is important to me to offer my customers a larger variety and in this way better my earnings and take care of our needs.

Translated from Spanish by Kiva Volunteer, Kristin Connor

Hola Mi nombre es Denia Iyodesa, mi actividad principal es el comercio, cuento con una pequeña pulperia de venta de productos para el consumo humano, ubicada en mi casa de habitación, gracia a este negocio puedo contribuir con los gastos familiares y atender a mi familia. Actualmente necesito surtir mas mi negocio ya que para mi es importante poder ofrecer al cliente mayor variedad y de esa forma mejorar los ingreso y por ende las utilidades.

loans.use: To purchase eggs, rice, sugar, coffee, flour, soap, butter, chicken, dairy products ham,corn and beans.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en: Madam C. lives in Pantang, Accra, Ghana and sells "kenkey" a local meal made from maize. She sells to schools in her community. She is seeking a loan of $500.00 so she can produce more food and sell to more school children.

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Belinda Yamilen

texts.en:
My name is Belinda and I am a merchant and owner of a small restaurant in the center of town, called "Comedor Belinda." I have several years experience in this field. My restaurant creates income enough to contribute to the payment of family expenses and to be able to offer my children a better standard of living, through which they will be able to have better opportunities in the future.

Translated from Spanish by Kiva Volunteer, Kristin Connor

Mi nombre el Belinda, soy comerciante cuento con un comedor en el centro de mi ciudad, llamado comerdor Belinda, tengo varios años de experiencia en este tipo de negocio, el que me genera ingreso para contribuir con los gastos familiares y de esa forma ofrecer a mi hijos un mejor nivel de vida, quienes en el futuro puedan tener mejores oportunidades.

loans.use: To purchase beans, refreshments, eggs, butter, rice, sugar, coffee, flour and other items.

loans.name: Kate

texts.en: Antie Kate owns a "chop bar" where she sells local meals and drinks. She wishes to open a restaurant in her locality. She is seeking a loan of $950.00 so she can realize this dream.

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Luis Adolfo

texts.en:
My name is Luis Adolfo and I work primarily as a merchant and owner of a grocery store called "Gracias a Dios" (Thanks to God), located in my own home in the center of my neighborhood. My grocery store creates enough income to cover personal expenses and other necessities. Now I have a need to establish a second location which will be run by my wife, because of which I need to stock more items.

Translated from Spanish by Kiva Volunteer, Kristin Connor

Mi nombre el Luis Adolfo, mi actividad principal es el comercio, cuento con una pulperia llada pulperia "Gracias a Dios" ubicada en mi casa de habitación en el centro de mi colonia, la que me genera ingresos para cubrir los gastos personales y otros compromisos, actualmente estoy estableciendo otro negocio para que sea atendido por mi esposa el que necesito surtir mas.

loans.use: To buy eggs, rice, sugar, coffee, butter, dairy products, soap and other items.

loans.name: Charlotte

texts.en: Charlotte sells baby's dresses from house to house in her community. She wishes to have her own shop where she can sell baby clothes. She is seeking a loan of $650.00 to enable her open a baby clothes shop, which will make her clothes available to more customers.

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Martha

texts.en: Martha operates a "chop bar" in her community. She sells meals the locals enjoy. A loan of $700.00 will enable her to buy the supplies necessary to cook and sell more foods and expand her trade.

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Jose Manuel

texts.en:
Hello, my name is Manuel A. and my primary job in the sale and repairing of bicycles. I have a small business located in the center of my community called "Repair Store:Super Bike." My store creates enough income to cover my family expenses and to other school costs of my children, with this business I have been able to advance my family.

Translated from Spanish by Kiva Volunteer, Kristin Connor

Hola Mi nombre es Manuel A., mi actividad principal es la venta y reparación de bicicletas, cuento con un pequeño negocio ubicado en el centro de mi comunidad llamado taller de repuestos Super Bike, el que me genera ingresos para cubrir mis gastos familiares, y demas gastos de estudio de mis hijos, ya que con este negocio he sacado adelante a mi familia.

loans.use: To purchase replacement cables, seats,handles,tires,gears, and other items.

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Philomina

texts.en: Philomina sells sewing materials to seamstresses in her community. She also sells stationery and school supplies to school children. She is seeking a loan of $700.00 so she can buy more stock, offer more to her customers, and increase her sales.

loans.use: Buy more sewing supplies and school supplies to sell

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Grace W. is 49 years old, married, and now a mother of two children (she used to have three more, but they died). She has spent twenty-three years running her small vegetable kiosk in the outskirts of Kisumu, Kenya. Grace has also started a cereal business to maximize her profits. Her hard work, perseverance, good reputation and many years in business, coupled with a well-established clientele, ensure that her business will continue to grow despite tough competition. Grace has received two previous loans worth US$572 from KMET - she used them to scale up her business in order to meet the growing demand. She has now applied for a loan of US$725 which she plans to use to purchase an additional stock of cereals to sell during the upcoming dry period when the community faces the risk of famine.

loans.use: Increase the cereal stock

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence O. is a very active 48-year old member of her community. She has lived in one of the slums of Kisumu, Kenya, for the past thirteen years. She is a widow and heads a household of five school-aged children, two of whom are orphans due to AIDS. She was trained by UNICEF as a community health worker in 1993. In 1997, she received training from KMET for home-based HIV/AIDS care, TB ambassadorship, and community-based distribution of oral contraceptives.

Florence is very well-known within her community for her compassionate work and also as a politician. She is the women’s representative for the Liberal Democratic Party in Kisumu District, where her principal role is to speak to women, raise awareness, and encourage their involvement in the political process to fight for their rights. As an expert in the art of making traditional baskets, Florence initiated a basket-weaving income-generating project for a group of women within her community five years ago, and she continues to lead and support this group. Her main business and source of income, however, is her community pharmacy which she has managed for the past eight years.

Thanks to her reputation and the location of her pharmacy within the community, her business has flourished. The most commonly purchased drugs in her pharmacy are those to treat malaria, diarrhea, asthma and upper respiratory infections. Florence credits her success to hard work and the assistance she has received from KMET through two previous microfinance loans. She plans to use the funds from her next loan of US$600 to expand both of her businesses. She will invest in a bulk stock of drugs for her community pharmacy and will purchase basket-weaving materials.

loans.use: Increase the pharmacy's drug stock and purchase materials for weaving baskets.

loans.name: Maria Vicenta

texts.en:
Hello, my name is Maria Vicenta and I have a store where I sell ice cream, in my own home, which creates enough income to contribute to the family expenses and more importantly, I can help take care of my family. I currently need to stock my store because summer is approaching and the demand for my goods is increasing.

Translated from Spanish by Kiva Volunteer, Kristin Connor

Hola mi nombre es Maria Vicenta, cuento con un negocio de venta de Helados en mi casa de habitacion, el que me genera ingreso para contribuir con los gastos familiares y lo mas importante es que puedo antender a mi familia, actualmente necesito surtir ya que estamos en la temporada de verano y el volumen de venta es mayor.

loans.use: To purchase ice cream, cones, disposable cups, spoons, napkins and other items.

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Teresa De Jesus

texts.en:
My name is Teresa and I am a merhcant, I have a small grocery store located in my own homw which creates enough income to contribute to family expenses. I have worked in my grocery store for several years and I have the help of my children in their spare time. I currently need to stock my store so that I can offer a wider variety of goods to my customers.

Translated from Spanish by Kiva Volunteer, Kristin Connor

Mi Nombre es Teresa soy comerciante, cuento con una pequeña pulperia ubicada en mi casa de habitación la que me genera ingresos para contribuir con los gastos de mi familia cuento con varios años de dedicarme a este tipo de actividad, cuento con el apoyo de mis hijos ya que en su tiempo libre ellos me colaboran en el negocio, actualmente necesito surtir mas y poder ofrecer mayor variedad de productos a mis clientes.

loans.use: To purchase rice, butter, sugar, soap, toilet paper, dairy goods, sausages and other items.

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Julia Ester

texts.en:
Hello my name is Julia Ester and I work primarily as a merchant, I have a grocery store called "La Estancia" (The Farm). I have had my business for several years and it creates enough income to contribute to the payment of family expenses and thanks to my store I have been able to give en education to my children.

Translated from Spanish by Kiva Volunteer, Kristin Connor

Hola mi nombre es Julia Ester, mi actividad principal el el comercio, cuento con un negocio de Pulperia, llamado Pulperia La Estancia, cuento con varios años de dedicarmen a este tipo de negocio el que me genera ingresos para contribuir con los gastos familiares, ya que gracias a este negocio he podido dar educacióm a mis hijos.

loans.use: To purchase sugar, refreshments, rice, butter, soap, sausages, dairy goods and other items.

loans.name: Pedro Antoonio

texts.en:
Hello my name is Pedro Antonio and I work primarily in the detailing and sales of shoes for all ages. I have had my business for several years and it creates enough income to cover family expenses and other necessities. Thanks to this business I can give an education to my children, who help me in their spare time since it is currently the school year. I need more material because the demand for my products has increased.

Translated from Spanish by Kiva Volunteer, Kristin Connor

Hola mi Nmbre es Pedro Antonio, mi actividad principal es la elaboracion y venta de zapatos para todas la edades tengo varios años de dedicarme a este tipo de actividad la que me genera ingresos para cubrir los gastos de mi familia y otros compromisos. gracias a este negocio puedo dar educación a mis hijos, quienes me colaboran en su tiempo libre, actualmente que es la espoca escolar necesito mas material ya que el volumen de venta es mayor.

loans.use: To purchase leather in all colors: black, red, brown, yellow, Italian made, suede,shoe sizers.

loans.name: Jose Martin

texts.en:
Hello my name is Jose Martin and I work primarily as a merchant, I have had a grocery store in my own home for several years now, which creates enough income to cover family expenses and other necessities. Thanks to this business I have given an education to my children and bettered my standard of living.

Translated from Spanish by Kiva Volunteer, Kristin Connor

Hola mi nombre el Jose Martin, mi actividad principal comercio, cuento con una pulperia en mi casa de habitación desde hace varios años, la que me genera ingresos para cubrir los gastos familiares y otros compromisos con proveedores, gracias sa este negocio e dado educacion a mis hijos y he logrado mejorar mi vivienda.

loans.use: To purchase rice, butter, beans, dairy goods, sausages, refreshments, oil, toilet paper, and other items.

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Herlinda  Trinidad

texts.en:
My name is Herlinda and I am a merchant, I have a grocery store in the center of my community and I have several years experience running my store. My business allows me to care for my family and more importantly, thanks to the store, I can contribute to the family expenses and other necessities. Currently, I need to stock my store because the demand has been increasing.

Translated from Spanish by Kiva Volunteer, Kristin Connor.

Mi nombre es Herlinda, mi actividad principal es el comercio, cuento con una pulperia ubicada en el centro de mi comunidad, tengo varios años de dedicarmen a este tipo de actividad, la que me permite atender a mi familia y para mi eso es muy importante, gracias a este negocio puedo contribuir con los gastos familiares y demas conpromisos con proveedores, actualmente necesito surtir mi negocio ya que la demanda a crecido.

loans.use: To purchase butter, rice, sugar, soap, refreshments, meats, beans, corn, milk and other items.

loans.name: Digna  Emerita

texts.en:
My name is Digna Emerita and I am a merchant, I have a business in which I sell new clothing, in the manner of a traveling saleswoman. I have several years experience, and my business creates enough income to cover family expenses. I currently am in need of a wider variety of products because the demand has increased and I do not have the capital readily available to satisfy my customers.

Translated from Spanish by Kiva Volunteer, Kristin Connor.

Mi nombre es Digna Emerita, mi actividad principal es el comercio, cuento con negocio de venta de ropa nueve la distribuyo de manera ambulante por encargo, tengo varios años de dedicarme a este tipo de actividad, la que me genera ingresos para cubrir los gastos familiares, actualmente necesito mas variedad de producto ya que la demanda a crecido y no cuento con el capital suficiente para satisfacer la clientela.

loans.use: To purchase men's shirts, women's blouses, socks, girl's and women's underwear.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: The money will be used to buy a new photcopier CANNON 1120 which will allow the owner to make copies in color and to increase clientel as well as the earnings from their business.

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Lesly Yesenia

texts.en:
My name is Lesly Yesenia and I am a merchant. I have a grocery store run from my own home and I have several years experience in this business which creates enough income to cover family expenses and the education costs of my children. I currently need to stock my store because the demand increases every day.

Translated from Spanish by Kiva Volunteer, Kristin Connor.

Mi nombre es Lesly Yesenia, mi actividad principal es el comercio. Cuento con una pulperia en mi casa de habitación, tengo varios años de dedicarme a este tipo de actividad la que me genera ingresos para cubrir los gastos de mi familia y gastos de educación de mis hijos, actualmente necesito surtir mi negocio, tomando en cuenta que la demanda cada día crece.

loans.use: To purchase rice, butter, dairy products, soap, toilet paper, refreshments, cosmetics and other items.

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Ana De Jesus

texts.en:
Hello my name is Ana and I am a merchant, I have a grocery store run from my own home, located in the center of my community. I have several years experience in this business which creates enough income to cover family expenses, as I am a single mother and thanks to this business I am able to give my children what they need.

Translated from Spanish by Kiva Volunteer, Kristin Connor.

Hola mi nombre es Ana, mi actividad principal es el comercio, cuento con una pulperia en mi casa de habitación, ubicada en el centro de mi comunidad, tengo varios años de dedicarme a este tipo de negocio el que me genera ingresos para cubrir los gastos familiares, ya que soy madre soltera y gracias a este negocio puedo dar a mi hijos lo necesario.

loans.use: To purchase sugar, butter, refreshments, coffee, instant soupd, eggs, rice, meats and sausages.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase a payphone, mobile phone accessories and an office for his business

loans.name: Avei

texts.en: Avei is one of the oldest members in the program, still doing well with her business. She’s 55 year old woman and is still strong with a bright mind.  Avei is now a grandmother of 26 grandchildren, and is looking after 9 of them. Avei started her shop from selling taro, bananas, coconuts and Samoan cocoa. Her shop is now one of the famous shops in the Falealii District about 35 kilometres from the town centre of Apia. But Avei still believes that she’s still strong and willing to expand and provide a much better service to her district. She’s requesting this loan to do maintenance to her shop and to set up a telephone centre to provide this service for people that don’t have phones.

loans.use: To renovate her shop, purchase additional stock and start a telephone rental business inside her shop

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To acquire fish filet stock, refregration equipment and rent a store for his first time fishmonger business

loans.name: Faamaumaga

texts.en: Faamuamaga is a 43 year old mother of 7 children, 2 living in New Zealand, 2 living in Samoa with their relatives, and 3 living together with her. Faamuamaga’s business is a taro plantation; she also grows vegetables, make brooms and cooks Samoan cocoa. Not only does she target the needs of older people, she also makes ice cream cakes to meet the need of the village kids. She dreams of owning and running a shop in the future. With her requested loan, Faamuamaga is planning to build a proper shop like house to start off her dream. She’ll still be selling the same products and would rely on her profit and the help from her husband who is a carpenter to stock up her shop slowly.

loans.use: Buy materials to build a small stall where she can sell her farm products.

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional equipment and assorted hair-care products for her salon business

loans.name: Faapaia

texts.en: Faapaia is a single 26 year old lady from the village of Levili -- about 5 kilometers from the town centre of Apia. Her business is pancakes which she is sells at the Fugalei market, which is the main market of Samoa.
